description:
Each order comes with a basket of tortilla chips, a side of guac, and spicy, spicy salsa.

Per my SO:

Pastor quesadilla - Tender, flavorful, oily pork. Overflowing with meat spilling out of the quesadilla. Smaller portions than most Mexican restaurants but rich in flavor. 

Carne asada quesadilla - Best carne asada in a while. Not dry for once. 

For the vegans: 

Nothing for you but a side of rice and beans. 

Rice and beans - Ordered the small (not listed on their menu) for $3.80 and the plate was filled with too much rice and beans for one girl to finish. Basic, salty, comforting dish.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
I flew in to SF super early and needed some food. I had a few places bookmarked but one had a long line and I was on the brink of Hangry so I popped in to Taqueria Cancun. I had noticed the small hole-in-the wall place on my first round of wandering and saw they had a sign advertising breakfast burritos. I'm in. I ended up bypassing the breakfast burrito for an entire breakfast plate (Hangry, remember). It came with scrambled eggs, chorizo, rice, refried beans, and tortillas. It was a large portion of food for $10! You also get free chips & salsa, always a plus. I ended up skipping most of the tortillas although they were really good. The food was super hot and fresh as they cook everything to order on a big flat top.

The food was definitely filling and comforting after a long flight, but it wasn't particularly flavorful. I ended up using all the salsa on the eggs to kick them up a bit. I did hear someone who requested their food to be spicy, so maybe that's key. The green salsa was amazing! I put it on everything. The guys working were all friendly and the food was done quickly. Note that they are a cash only establishment but they have an on-site ATM.
author: Katy C.

description:
Good food located in a sketchy neighborhood. You will see many homeless people. You will smell a bad stench. You will see crackheads. But, just keep to yourself and you should be fine. Go inside, get the food then get the f out. 

The menu is pretty straightforward - burrito, taco, nacho, etc. I ordered the carne asada super burrito. My colleagues got a mixture of stuff. The super burrito was pretty big. It did feel like a super burrito, loaded with rice, bean, beef, gauc, cilantro, and sour cream, and grease. Gotta have the grease for it to be moist and juicy. This ain't a healthy gluten free place. If you want healthy, this place ain't it. 

This is a hole in the wall restaurant with good food. And it's on the authentic side. Btw, the employees are not very friendly. You come, you order and they give you your food. It won't be smiley faces with small talk. Also, it's cash only make sure to bring cash!
author: Ngoc P.

description: Who says you get what you pay for? If you're looking for the best taco or the cheapest taco in San Francisco, look no further than this delightfully gritty taqueria on Market Street. You might have to navigate plenty of sf's famously colorful street characters. But that's part of the joy of visiting this great city.
author: Ken K.

description: I thought Tu Lan opened at 10am and when I discovered it would be another hour I needed a quick bite to eat. Taqueria Cancun was right there so in I went. Not the best Mexican food in the world-not the worst-but it was tasty and definitely served it's purpose
author: Matthew S.

description: Bought a chicken super burrito with black beans. It was okay, but I didn't think it was seasoned well enough; it was rather on the bland side, even with the salsa added to it. It cost about $11.50 including the tax. For the money, it was a lot of food, but I just wish it was a bit spicier and had more flavor. The guys working there were nice!
author: Annie W.

description:
Not all burritos are created equal. The same holds true for Taqueria Cancun and I'm not talking about with regards to other restaurants, but their own burritos are inconsistent with each other. 

For instance, their carne asada burrito is absolutely delicious. The carne is usually flavorful and moist. However, the chicken burrito was probably the most bland I've ever had. 

Ca$h only and seating is very limited. Sits roughly about 4 people. 

Location is sketch. There's always someone right outside either panhandling or trying to sell you some random items. 

Open late night. They do whip out your order really fast so you're never waiting too long.
author: Ann S.

description: Hands down the best burrito I've ever had. I ordered the Super burrito with carne asada (~$10 with tax). The burrito is as long as my forearm and I ate it for like three separate meals. The put fresh avocado slices in it which is AMAZIN'. Cash only. You know I'll be back.
author: Jamie J.

description:
I was walking on Market st on the way to get to El Castillito on 14th & Church st.
I decided to stop and get my burrito here.
a big mistake.
portion was big, but no flavors.
I ordered Super Burrito al pastor, such a disappointment.
there are many better one in San Francisco.
author: Rudy H.

description: You want authentic Mexican food this is the place. Meat well seasoned, torta is delish and the burrito is juicy.
author: Delia G.

description:
This place wasn't bad. A few ups, a few downs. If you're sketched out about "not-so-nice" neighborhoods, then don't come here. Relaxed atmosphere and relaxed staff. Everything looks super fresh and the salsa is awesome! Both the red and green are the tastiest salsas I have ever had at a restaurant. 
I ordered the al pastor super burrito and the meat was delicious but the overall burrito lacked a little flavor. The total was about $10 per burrito and I feel like that was a little overpriced. I would definitely go back for a taco or something else. It also came with some chips and salsa on the side and I was unimpressed by the chips. Big burritos, little flavor.
author: Anissa R.

description:
A couple of days ago I ended up at Taqueria Cancun as Tu Lan was closed by the time I got there and this was the closest place open at the time. As this is a sketchy part of town I ignored the pan handler outside and stepped in. Taqueria Cancun is your typical Mexican joint serving tacos, burritos, quesadilla, meat plates with rice and beans etc. After going through the menu I decided to get the wet burrito which here is called the Burrito Mojado ($9.25) with Cabeza. When paying I was told that it was cash only so I paid in cash.

I sat on one of the tables that had a sticky surface so kept by elbows off and observed the chef putting my burrito together. It was your standard drill tortilla rice, beans, meat and fold, After he assembled the burrito he placed it in a plastic container and proceeded to heat it up in the microwave. What? This is not done. If I want to have a frozen burrito I'll get one from the freezer section of a super market and heat it up myself. No need to come to a Taqueria. Also don't they know that plastic leaks into the food when placed in a microwave? I knew that this was going to be bad. After heating the burrito in the microwave, I saw the chef throw on some guacamole and sour cream on top which completed this masterpiece. Before leaving I tried to look for a salsa bar but there was none. Instead I found 2 tiny containers with red and green salsa in the to-go container when I reached home.

Let's come to the food. This was one sad looking burrito. It was supposed to be a wet burrito but all that it had was a minuscule amount of red salsa poured on top most of which was just water (see my picture). Anyway after draining the water I dug in. First bite told me that instead of Cabeza they had given me lengua. Now this would not be a problem as I like lengua, but this was the gamiest lengua that I've ever had. It had such a strong smell that I could barely swallow this crap. After a couple of bites I threw in the towel and safely consigned the remaining burrito to the trash can.

Big mistake, I should have taken the pain of walking to Tropisueño and got something from there before heading home instead of being lazy and getting something from here. This is an absolute rip off joint that I have no intention of coming back to.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
OK, this is the more barebones Cancun location out of all of them, but the quality and service is still the same. They have the same grimey atm, almost empty water jug, dim, yellowish lighting. Tasty burrito heaven. 

I always get the vegetarian burrito here, which is both hefty and easily consumed, if you're really hungry. I try to eat the chips first, but if the food comes fast, they end up abandoned at the end of the table, a commonly seen Cancun ritual.
author: Morgen B.

description: Ordered the Super Burrito to split, it came out quickly and we found a spot inside to eat since it was slower on a Sunday afternoon. Nothing extremely flavorful, but a well-packed burrito. I could barely hold it, and it was so full we had to finish it with a fork. It was around $10, and for two people it was great, but I probably wouldn't return solely for the food. It was a standard Mexican meal but I've had better burritos. Not a must-have but good if you're in the area and want a quick bite.
author: Jenna K.

description: Saw a drug deal from a homeless person. However, the food was good enough to keep me eating while surrounded by street chaos.
author: Coleman T.

description: Pretty good place when you're really craving Mexican food. The chips they give you are yummy too. However, I got the chicken burrito and it was a little dry. The vegetarian burrito was better because it had more sour cream/other sauces. Overall good place to fill you up!
author: Joanmarie S.

description: YUM. I got the carne asada super burrito and it was amazing. The place is cash only but has an ATM on site if you need to withdraw cash to pay. I went for lunch on a Monday so the vibe may have been different than usual, but it was a little quiet and didn't have the usual feel I expect in a Mexican place.
author: Emily S.

description:
Ok chicken burrito. Flour tortillas was great. The food was so so no flavor unless you poured salsa all over to eat. 
What happened to seasoning the meat or beans before you cook? Not the worst but no where near the best. 
Large enough for sure just void of any flavor
author: Karal K.

description:
First of all, I knew I was risking it with the location...middle of crackhead drive and methface street, but I was hungover and in serious need of a burrito. 

What was good: it was edible

What was bad: 
1. Took over 15 minutes to get my (meatless) burrito. It was not crowded. 
2. Health score was 82
3. People working were not friendly
4. Meatless burrito comes with avocado...and they left it out! Minus all-stars for the missing avocado. 


I could forgive 1-3 but messing up on #4 is just too much for me to handle. They only get 2 stars since I'm going to eat the boring ass burrito. 

Tip: hit up Taqueria Cancun on 19th and Mission, skip this hole in the wall
author: Nikki M.

description: I came here when they weren't busy.... Me an another guy was in line y'all took the guys order then let me stand there for 10 mins nobody doing anything but ignoring me thank you Taqueria Cancun for helping me find Taqueria Castillo B at 10 Mason St BEST DAMN SUPER NACHOS IN SAN FRANCISCO!!!!!!!!!
author: Rolin S.

description:
Had the veggie burrito eight dollars mostly rice, not good tasting. 
Nachos were a complete disaster, they put refried beans and white cheese on top of chips then microwaved NASTY! $8.00
I would never recommend and never be back. 
Decour is horrible.
author: Rod D.

description:
Horrible consistency,
I always order the same thing, beef and cheese burrito with no avocado. sometimes there are way too many beans, too much rice, other times too little cheese, and just right now they put the cheese on the side (not even on the burrito! he put some cheese in aluminum foil for my beef and cheese burrito! *refer to photo) because they "don't usually do that." Nachos are alright. It's a shame because when this taqueria did get my order right it would taste great.
author: Britney P.

description:
I really enjoy the food from this place, but I'm absolutely horrified by what I see when I come here. For example...

While enjoying a tasty burrito, a deranged man walked in and grabbed a customer's wet (sour cream soaked) burrito from his plate and ran out. Sour cream was all over the table, floor and customer.

Another time, a deranged man walked in, grabbed 100 napkins, took off his shirt and wiped down his entire body in front of the wall mirror. 

I can't blame Cancun for either of these incidents; however, the staff seemed more amused than concerned by everything. Admittedly, it didn't bother me enough to stop coming here and eating delicious burritos.
author: Nick K.

description:
Whoa this place was good. I got just one chicken taco, and it was so flavorful. Even though I asked for no spice, it was still really spicy, but in a good way. Also, there was so much chicken, that there was no way I'd be able to pick it up and eat it as a taco. It also comes with free chips and green and red salsa! 

The two reasons why I took off one star is that the prices are pretty steep ($3 for one taco), and the location is in a pretty sketch part of town. Or at least, as someone who's from out of town, that's the vibe I got walking to it. I'm sure this wouldn't be a problem in the day, but I was getting a late night snack, and I definitely felt like I had to pick up my walking pace a little.
author: Austin T.

description:
Pretty decent Mexican food. 
Pros- many menu options 
           Fast service 
           Can see the cooking area
           Free chips and salsa 
           Whole beans
          Re fried beans or black
          If you are social.. communal tables 
 Cons- hole in the wall
            In the TLs 
          
So I had a regular breakfast burrito in the middle of the afternoon. Nice size. Made to order. Pretty good. I ate the whole thing. The salsa was ok the green is better than the red... the chips eh, they are free... so not horrible.
I also had a melon auga Fresca wich was pretty damn good. So all in all I would go back.
author: vita k.

description:
My first time in San Francisco and everybody told me to go get a burrito. Reading the reviews about this place I couldn't wait to sink my teeth into it's fair. I was pleasantly surprised how good the food was in this very simple place. Not only was the food delicious but well priced. The friendly staff gave recommendations and I decided to order the chicken burrito. The burrito was delicious full of flavor and the size of my arm for a reasonable price.

My suggestion if you're in San Francisco stop by here for one of the best burritos I've ever had coast to coast.
author: Joe G.

description: All the food was good seasoned, the prices are incredible, it is a good place for try Mexican food. The neighborhood is not so nice but this is not their fault.
author: Oscar M.

description:
This has been my favorite place for 3 years running. The atmosphere is pretty low quality so 4* is all due to the food taken out. Think comfort food more than brag worthy cullinary experience

My recommendation: go for a super burrito carnitas with refried beans. It comes with some ok tortilla chips and good salsas. 

Ways they could improve: 
have a salsa bar like other places where you can choose which and how many salsa you want.

 Casa Sanchez chips are better than theirs. May as well just hand those out instead of the less good ones. 


Note: cash only
author: Mike G.

description:
One of the best burritos I've ever had in my life. Came here after reading rave reviews on Thrillist. I ordered the prawn super burrito which seamed to be their specialty. They do not skimp on anything here. The burrito was stuffed with fresh large shrimp. Everyone also gets their own side of chips and salsa which was nice.

The horchata was a little grimy at the bottom so I ended up not being able to drink all of it. 

Portions are outrageous. You should split with someone else. Don't be a hero.
author: Carleigh R.

description:
3.5, but I'll round up since it's a convenient lunch option. 

SF burritos pale in comparison to Oakland 'rritos, and this isn't up to par with La Taqueria or El Farolito. But it's not bad by any means, they're right out of the BART station, right on Market where tons of people work, and the line moves quickly during the lunch rush. There's an ATM inside in case you forget cash and my super alpastor burrito is always way too much food for me. My vegetarian coworker also raves about their veggie burrito as well. 

Salsa leaves a bit to be desired. It's on Market so there's sketch people outside. But for a quick lunch fix, Taqueria Cancun is one of my top options.
author: Angela L.

description:
Came here after finding them on a website which recommended this restaurant as one of the top 10 local places to eat while in San Francisco. I was here in San Francisco for the weekend visiting from New Jersey. I ordered a regular chorizo burrito with an horchata as a drink. The food was pretty good. The restaurant is very small with limited seating, so if it's full then chances are you'll be standing waiting for a table to open up or you'll just have to get the food to go. The price was a little expensive. The burrito was decently priced at about $8.49, but I guess ordering a large horchata to drink was probably at least $5 or $6 because my total came out to be over $14, too much in my opinion. This place only accepts cash so make sure you bring cash. They do have an ATM inside. All in all, I'd visit again if I were in San Francisco a second time.

UPDATE: woke up the next morning with an upset stomach. The burrito was the last meal I had the night before.
author: M. A.

description:
Meh...smh

But it's all to the good. 
I'd hit Mission and Valencia for better.
author: Grubbinator A.

description:
Oh my. Oh my, oh my.

This place was amazing. We ate here twice during GDC, it was on the short walk between our hotel and the Moscone Centre, and we were utterly satisfied each time. I had both the veggie burrito, and the beef mojado (self-styled "wetback burrito") which was humongous and utterly delicious.

The interior is cramped and hot, which I couldn't really care less about, but some might, so if you are then I recommend using this as a take-out.

Despite being tight we never had an issue with finding a seat nor felt rushed to get up and go immediately after finishing. The dishes were served with some nachos (which were pretty good) and a couple of great tasting salsas.

Overall I can hardly recommend this place more, if you're in mid-market and fancy a treat then give it a go!
author: Jack W.

description: Located in a very tight space, they sling some mean burritos and tacos. The veggie burrito is my favorite. It's a hefty portion. Chips are standard. Their salsas, while small, pack some flavor and a little heat. Seating is limited.
author: Jack-Daniyel S.

description: This place is the bomb. I've been here two drunk weekends in a row and convinced my office to order them for catering! Their salsa is so hot but impossible to stop eating! Definition twig recommended for a late night stop if you're out and about in the mission.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
These burritos are humongous and amazing. Good stuff overall. I like the location, even if it's a bit smallish. Narrow is probably a better description. 

I like that the prices are reasonable (for San Francisco) and the place has a family-owned-diner sort of feel. Not sure if that's actually the case, but the stuff is good. All kinds of people here, from immigrants to urban hipsters.
author: Jimmy H.

description: Pretty damn decent burrito. Even with all the beans, rice, guac, sour cream and salsa on the burrito mojado, the carnitas stuffed inside were still crispy.
author: Andrew F.

description:
Been living by this place for 10 years now, once in a great while giving it another chance. I'm done. Their food tastes like the soap they spray on their outside  sidewalk speckle does with piss and shite. They only offer super spicy salsa, so your soapy burrito is left dry if you are of the mild tongue. Service is rude as well, and I'm an easy customer. 
Soap + only super spice +dryness + rudeness? Think I've given this surprisingly overrated place it's last chance.
Now to the toilet to hurl that soapy burrito...
author: Marissa R.

description:
Well, it was cleaner than expected based on their street sign at least.

For a taqueria, this place is pretty overpriced: a quesadilla cost $8 (and that was their "medium" level quesadilla). They do make everything fresh, but $8 got me some cheese, sliced meat, and a tortilla. I guess in SF you pay a premium even at a taqueria? (Probably not their fault as I imagine their rent is sky high...)

They are, however, relatively speedy (looking at you Show Dogs...) and conveniently located by the SHN Golden Gate Theater if one needs a bite before a show (as we did).

There are a few benches inside, otherwise this is a grab and go place. We pretty much came here out of desperation for needing something to eat quickly before the show, and at that price point, probably wouldn't come back otherwise.
author: Christine Y.

description:
You seriously need to go this place, Just look at that amazing Burrito Mojado, hands down the best Mexican food I've ever had in my life. 

Although the location might not be the best, this place has amazing food, if you are in San Francisco and you love Mexican food you MUST TRY this place
author: Tomás S.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars. I recommend this place during the day when you are hungover. 

Interior is standard for Mexican restaurants with very friendly staff. They slice the meat fresh, which I can appreciate.  

I ordered a Super Carne Asada Burrito with black beans. While it was delicious, if you are looking for something spicy, this is not the place for you. The burrito was better than I expected and they gave me complimentary chips and salsa, which I can appreciate. 

I was not a fan of the salsa as it was very cold: a small container of pico de gallo and a frozen salsa verde (which I tossed because I am not a fan of salsa popsicles). It seems they pack and freeze these little containers ahead of time and then unfreeze them to serve. The chips were okay but a bit stale. 

The burrito was exceptional with regard to the cheese factor. There was cheese in every bite which is hard to find these days. I normally only eat half of burritos but this was so cheesy and delicious, I gobbled up the entire thing in one sitting. I was pleasantly surprised by how generous they were with the avocado in this burrito as most places seem to skimp on this. 

As a heads up, the pricing listed on Yelp is super outdated. I paid just over $10 for my meal as everything on menus is at least $2-3 more than listed on here.
author: Ashley M.

description: Had a burrito with high hopes based on Thrillist reviews. Very sub-par. I ate half of my burrito and felt very heavy. Also, a little too salty for my taste.
author: Bryant E.

description:
The carne asada tacos are fantastic. They seem pricey but they give you tons of meat. If you like classic street tacos you'll like these. 

Also the salsa verde is fire
author: Michael R.

description:
Cancun does the basics, but it brings the Mission to 6th and Market for all of us workers in SoMa.

The space is super small, but the workers are really, really nice, and the burritos are exactly how you would expect them to be. Nothing exception, but a solid staple.
author: Christina S.

description: Unparalleled burritos. Sauce is a simmered masterwork. Chips the finest on the city. Eat here
author: Terry G.

description:
I feel like I should add a star for this place being one of the few places that actually makes their veggie burritos so they are warm all the way through but I still have trouble giving them all five stars because they're like 4, maybe four and a half on a good day. However, I've had so many veggie burritos that have insides that are about the temperature of those Japanese style ice cream crepe things I've started to come here more.

This place has gotten more expensive though. It's kind of hitting it's price point... too much more expensive and I'll be making my own veggie burritos. Maybe it was the ~$8 for a burrito containing nothing but cheese, veggies, and beans that kept me from the 5th star. But I suppose with the recent increase in cost of doing business in Mid Market it's not so bad.

If you're from LA or much of SoCal, really, you may be disappointed. Most of this city's taqueria faire will disappoint you. You're a tough (and by "tough" I mean in the most loving way "spoiled") crowd. (May I suggest some Japanese food--- particularly sushi--- if you're looking for something you just can't get better in LA?) But for you NorCal folks this place is pretty good. 

If you're vegetarian you should go here because you're food will be warm and yummy. If you're super strict vegan or "it can't touch any meat ever" vegetarian this isn't the place. But I've never gotten anything with large stray chunks of meat in it here (another problem elsewhere).... so win?!  

Yes, the area is still sketchy at night. But I'm from here and you aren't likely to get murdered on 6th Street at night (anymore). If you're uncomfortable, hey, it's gentrification... nobody forced you to come here. You may feel uncomfortable if you're not from the area but these guys have worked here forever and can hold down the place fine, even if the clientele can get a bit "interesting".
author: A J.

description: Can't beat the quality and generous size of their burritos. I recommend carne asada or the chorizo breakfast.
author: Gen G.

description: don't believe the hipsters. this place is burrito heaven. sure, it's on one of the grimiest corners in the city (and it's hardly less grimy inside) but realness is an essential burrito ingredient. tortilla, rice, beans, avocado, perhaps some carne, salsa, and realness.
author: Ronny K.

description:
This sh*thole makes some solid 'ritos!

Grabbed a carne asada Burrito Mojado (steak, rice, beans, onions, cilantro, salsa, topped with enchilada sauce, green salsa, melted cheese, sour cream & Mexican salsa) and was pleasantly surprised. The 'rito was massive. Prob a 3 pounder. The mix of salsas and sour cream gave each bite a different taste, which keeps you from getting bored after a pound of rolled up eats. With a price tag under $6, it's worth shooing away the crazy bums and waiting for a table in this piece. Enjoy.
author: Drew A.

description: Their food was very good. I order a burrito and torta de carne asada. They were very attentive and gave us extra chips and sauce. Great customer service, the price is reasonable. The place is very small so you might not be able to eat there.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
I walked into Taqueria Cancun my first weekend in San Francisco. My roommate was raving about having to try a proper burrito and this was his favorite spot. As a burrito lover, I look back on that day as a beautiful moment that changed how I rate burritos forever.

FREQUENCY: I've dined at this establishment more times than I can count (and I've only lived in SF for 3-4 months). I had to cut back to once a week because I like to stay healthy and fit and I was probably eating about 3 of these burritos per week.

FOOD: Get the super burrito. Taqueria Cancun has other items on their menu but it might as well not be there at all. They have about 8 different meats to choose from (or vegetarian if you prefer) and I've tried them all. Each is delicious but my go to at this point is Al Pastor. Your burrito will come with chips plus one green and red salsa cup. I prefer the green salsa so now I ask for two green salsa's. I can't speak enough about how amazing the burrito's are here. I grew up on the East Coast and I'll honestly probably never order a burrito when back home ever again. San Francisco Super Burrito's and San Diego California Burrito's have spoiled me. TRY THIS BURRITO! It's the first thing I take any visitors to do. And it's under $10 for a mound of food.

DRINK: Taqueria Cancun offers a good selection of beer, fountain drinks, and water. I'm personally a fan of a Pacifico with my burrito but my buddy gets the soda and really enjoys that too. 

ATMOSPHERE: Taqueria Cancun has the standard vibe for a taqueria in the Mission. Tables are usually filled with people having conversation and it can get a little loud at times. Plus depending on the time of day the line may be out the door. I promise it's worth the wait. But I've learned when they are and aren't busy from my multiple visits.

STAFF: I have literally never spoken more than my burrito order to the staff. They are quite and keep to themselves but since they are all behind a counter making food I don't mind nor am I offended. They have consistently made me amazing food so they get 5 stars in my book.

PAYMENT: Taqueria Cancun is cash only. They have ATM's on site.

There is one location in The Mission and one location in SoMa. Both are awesome and I go to each one regularly. If there is one thing that anyone takes away from my Yelp profile it is to try a burrito at this place!
author: Christopher D.

description: Best beef tacos I've ever had! Don't mind the stray pigeons - this taco joint is well worth the trek to this offbeat neighbourhood in SF.
author: Sadia H.

description:
Cheap: check!
HUGE ASS portion: check!
Cash only :(
Friendly guy making my burrito is always a plus :)
author: Katie N.

description: Turn up at beauty bar. Leave at 1:45. Cross the street to Cancun. Order 2 pastor super tacos. Stuff your beautifully drunken face. Go home. Fall asleep with make up still on and sour cream in hair. Wake up hungover, but happy that you had a successful night.
author: Bianca W.

description:
I found Taqueria Cancun using my Yelp app (searching for burritos while visiting San Fran). It was located near my hotel in Union Square, so I walked over for a quick meal. The restaurant is really small and easy to miss. There are a few tables inside but it's more of a takeout spot. I ordered a chicken super burrito with no beans (chicken, cheese, salsa, cilantro, sour cream, guacamole, & rice). Taqueria Cancun burritos come with a side of chips & salsa/Verde. I thought the burrito was tasty and filling. I'm a tall guy and I  was stuffed after eating my burrito. All of the ingredients blended well together. Prices were reasonable for most items. Service was fast and food comes out hot. Taqueria Cancun is a good choice for burritos in Union Square. I give Taqueria Cancun a 3.5 rating.
 
CASH ONLY!!! An ATM machine is located inside the restaurant.
author: Dominic B.

description:
Coming from AZ I have been somewhat spoiled with mexican food. I've had it all- and Taqueria Cancun unfortunately did not satisfy.

I live/work in twitterloin so exterior appearances do not phase me, neither did the trash on the floor under the tables or the unclean tables. I had my mind set on some nachos. I ordered the super nachos with chorizo and a super quesadilla with chicken.  My total came to $19.55, which I happily forked over in anticipation of my meal.

What I got was a sad mess of "mexican food"-

They give you a basket of cold stale tortilla chips and two small salsa containers (each about 2oz) and there is no salsa bar. 

Soon my food came up and as soon as I started eating my nachos I noticed they forgot the chorizo, but the nachos were so nasty I did not even bother to tell them. The nachos were soggy as soon as I started eating because they were completely covered in watery sour cream, I had to dig for chips that actually had cheese on it (it had mostly beans) and the only thing I ended up enjoying was the whole slices of avocado. 

My super quesadilla was a similar experience, while it could have been good it was also soaked in the watery sour cream mess that literally made the whole thing soggy. 

Skip this place-
author: Travis B.

description:
I've always really liked Cancun burritos (at least from the 19th & Mission location) and thought I'd stop into the Market location for a quick bite. All i had on me was a $10 bill. Perfect. One super burrito coming up, right? Wrong. The bill was a little torn (not all the way through, just a rip). The guy who took my order looks at it, then waves me off and turns away muttering "I don't have tape." WTF? It's just a little ripped. I try to explain to him that the bill is perfectly legal tender but he just keeps repeating "I don't have tape." 

Well, I'm starving, so I head out and up to the Blick art store on the next block. They have tape. I tape up the bill and head back. Dude behind the counter ignores me, serves a few other customers, then looks at me like he's never seen me before. "Yes?" "I'd like to re-order my pollo asado super burrito, black beans." 

He looks at the bill and shakes his head. There is a little tear in the corner - one of the numeral 10s is partially missing. He says he can't take it. "My boss doesn't let me." Can kinda tell he's enjoying this.  WT ever-loving F???? 

I went to Castillo on Mason. Lovely people and great burritos. Don't think I'll ever patronize Cancun again. Talk about leaving a bad taste in the mouth. Major jerks at this location. Soured me on the whole place.
author: Calum G.

description:
I have passed this little shop so many time before so I figured I would give it a shot.  It has all the potential to be a great hidden gem as it is tucked away in a transitional area of mid-market. I had the super burrito which was about $10, it was massive but really lacked flavor.

Very disapointed on the taste and will not be back.
author: Frank C.

description:
Got a Burrito here before going out to party at Mezzanine.  Figured I needed something in my stomach before throwing back a few.  

This was my first time to this Cancun as I usually find my way to the one in the mission, but no time for that on this night.  No line, and the place was fairly empty.  A couple of homeless guys were asking for change.  Not too surprising for the area.  

The burrito was good, but not great like the other location.  Slightly above standard fair for a Carne Asada burritos.
author: Veasna H.

description:
I had high hopes for this place. It was okay.

We got breakfast burritos here the other day and paid extra ($1.50?) for the super. Each burrito was $8.50 before tax. 

I asked for no sour cream and no rice, and instead got sour cream and no beans (I wanted beans!!). If they can't handle modifications, they should say so.

Also, the burritos with special requests were significantly smaller than the ones without modifications. Some places seem to make up for it by giving a little more of the other ingredients, but not this place -- even if you pay for the super size.

Other than that, it was a good breakfast burrito, but not my favorite. Hard to say though, because every bite had the gross melted sour cream that I asked them to leave out. I did like that it came with avocado.
author: Jennifer R.

description: Really good value for your money. Burritos are gigantic and taste great. Service is standard, and pretty quick if you're on the go. 50/50 chance you'll have a bench to sit at depending on when you go. A hole in the wall that shouldn't disappoint, and probably your best second choice if you had to make one. Cash only, too.
author: David N.

description:
I got the chicken super burrito, I enjoyed it. My taste buds aren't refined enough to differentiate between burrito brothers; I detect no difference between this burrito and the ones I've gotten at the mission location. 

Cash only. I had to borrow some money from a friend. Little did I know there's an ATM inside. It's kind of a tight squeeze so if you have to use the ATM make sure someone has your spot in line.

Tight spot. This spot is definitely more crammed than the other Taqueria Cancun in the mission. The line area is parallel to the dining area. It ain't so bad; it moves pretty quick. But the burrito train lets off to nowhere so you're gonna be chillin by the cashier/cooler area for a hot moment. 

Don't worry your 'rito is coming right up. Don't get too overzealous; other people probably ordered the chicken super burrito as well so do your math and make sure the one they're calling out is yours. Otherwise you're gonna look like an asshole; a post-line overzealous burrito hoarding asshole. Honestly this place is not big enough for fifteen people hassling the cooks wasting their time "is that mine I think that one is mine". You know what order your order went in; that's some zen shit right there.

Infinitely more interesting clientele. Saw a guy in line wearing overalls with an epic celestial odyssey depicted on them; that motherfucker was born ready to get his super burrito on.

Have fun and dang the chips aren't great so use the provided salsa.
author: Patrick A.

description: Decent $10 burrito but not the best I've had. Will definitely fill you up and for the price could be what you are looking for.
author: Spencer B.

description:
Smells bad in here..really bad...like rotten onions mixed with hobos. I've gotten harassed here by some homeless lady..yes I was scared. The first time I had the burrito it was OKAY. It wasn't that good. But the more I come here the better it taste! 

I usually get ONE taco only cuz it's huge and I'm on a diet so I shouldn't eat a whole burrito. All the entrees come with free chips and salsa although I'm scared they're gonna change their policy because of me and my one taco way.... I like the red salsa that they give you. It's spicy! A little too spicy for me..but still delicious!! The green salsa tastes like gasoline. Wtf so I always trash it. Next time I should ask if they can replace the green salsa with the red salsa. Seriously though..it tastes like durian .. Or gasoline?!?!?

Carne asada..always! 8)
author: Stephanie W.

description: It's gritty. But it's delicious.  Area has a lot of shady people but that super veggie burrito !!!
author: Kevin G.

description: Great small burrito joint. I enjoy the veggie burrito. Also good as a wet burrito. They take cash only, but there's an ATM if needed.
author: Nikolais L.

description: I love Mexican food and Taqueria Cancun has had one of the best burritos I have had in San Francisco so far (if not the best). I am not a fan of rice and beans and what not on my burrito so I get mine with 3 ingredients: carnitas, avocado, and cheese. So. Freaking. Good. The burrito is probably not healthy at all, but it sure is delicious. Carnitas have been super tasty and nicely cooked, the avocado adds a little creaminess, and the cheese ties it all together. Their tortillas are also quite good, really sauce and they hold the burrito together well so it doesn't fall apart and make a mess. The food here is cheap too (the super burrito which has everything I mentioned plus rice, beans, onions, and salsa) is under $8 and comes with chips and salsa. They have been fairly busy when I've been there, but not to the point where you have to wait a long time and I have usually seen some seats available. Cash only but there's an ATM inside (with a $2 fee). Pro tip: get food here, and then take it around the corner to Showdown Bar to eat and grab a beer.
author: Seema U.

description:
Yes, the place is narrow, making clever use of a tiny space.

Yes, the door is sometimes open when it'd be a bit warmer to close it.

Yes, the locals-san-housing do occasionally come in, adding to the ambiance.

Yes, the food is inexpensive and very satisfying. In the half-year I've lived near-by, I've had the tacos, the burrito mojados, regular burritos, breakfast burritos, and a few things I've forgotten since I started writing this review. All were tasty and my wallet was unharmed.

TIP: Try a burrito with chorizo -- damn tasty!

TIP: My lower-carb burrito is +chorizo -rice -beans.
author: Michael S.

description: The food is straight disgusting.  I'm so mad I wasted my time and money on food from here.  My big burrito taste like dish water.   Looks pretty but that's about it. I'm so disgusted.
author: Chante S.

description: I used to volunteer near taqueria cancun and can I just say I LOVE THIS PLACE. The lines get super long and it isn't in the best part of town but the food tastes authentic and AMAZING. I honestly think it is one of the better Mexican places in the city. The tacos all taste very fresh and the meats are well seasoned. Try the super tacos! Add avocado to everything!! I don't normally order chicken at a Mexican joint but I really like the chicken plate here too. The onion really balances out the heaviness of the beans and sour cream and they give you so much food for a reasonable price. Their salsas are great too!! If you are in the area you should definitely check this place out. Just beware that there is very little room to sit and it doesn't look like the cleanest place in the world... But I think it is amazing. I don't think twice about going out of my way to eat here or bringing takeout back for my family!
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
**Gary D and the Burritozombie Apocalypse**

68 and sunny, light breeze, no afternoon meetings, and craving hard for a burrito. Perfect conditions to stroll on over to the Civic Center location of Taqueria Cancun, purveyors of the best burritos on the planet.

I almost lose my appetite wading through a sea of half-naked panhandlers on Market, but I know the craving will return. It always does.

No line. Looks like I beat the noon rush! As I enter, I marvel at how the Civic Center location still feels so much like a true authentic Mission District joint. Cramped, dingy, steamy, with a thick layer of solidified burrito essence slathered on every tabletop. Yup, I'll be taking this one to-go. How these places pass health inspection is beyond me, but there is no denying that Taqueria Cancun makes an awesome burrito. 

"Numero veinte!"

As I grab my order, I notice the now-substantial line of drooling burrito-eyeing onlookers spilling out the door. I proceed toward the exit, flinging elbows to clear a path. I emerge into daylight, to find the mass of hungry half-naked homeless dudes gathered menacingly before me.

"Burrito..."

They chant in unison, arms outstretched, reaching longingly for my goods.

"Burrito..."

Their eyes reveal an insatiable lust for the foil-shrouded carnitas super burrito within the paper bag laying flat across my splayed left hand.

"Burrito..."

Channeling the great Barry Sanders, in one fluid motion I cradle the prize in my right arm, thrust out a vicious stiff-arm that drenches my left hand in mucus and saliva, and spin free from the crowd. I dash into the Civic Center BART station, resisting the urge to spike the football as I cross the faregates in triumph, safe from my burritozombie pursuers.

I descend the broken escalator and hop onto a train as its doors slide shut, locking me into a musty old carpeted car with grungy upholstered seats teeming with penicillin-resistant bacteria. Heart pounding and chest heaving after my close escape, I am forced to inhale the foul air. I barely stave off nausea as the train pulls into Montgomery station.

I finally arrive at the office, thoroughly disinfect myself in the washroom, and head to the lunch room. Ahhhh...alone at last with my Taqueria Cancun carnitas super burrito, which by now has marinated for an extra 30 minutes. I savor every bite of the moist, tasty masterpiece while daydreaming of my next adventure through burritozombie-infested lands.


Morals of this story:
- A tightly-wrapped burrito sitting in its own juices for half an hour is a glorious thing. Just make sure they don't fake the juice by splashing salsa-water into your burrito, as that will destroy the integrity of the tortilla. No worries at Taqueria Cancun, where you'll get a legitimately moist burrito that won't fall apart or get overly soggy.
- Consider using TaskRabbit to avoid the burritozombie apocalypse on Market Street and all the germs that downtown SF has to offer. Just don't shake hands with your delivery dude.
- Minus two stars for ambience, dropping from six stars to four. Geez, this place is so disgusting that I'd actually go into the Mission District for cleanliness.
- Few places have the power to restore your appetite after the unpleasant nastiness described above. Taqueria Cancun is one. Truly marvelous.
author: Gary D.

description:
BOMB FOOD. i have been to A LOT of taqueria and let me tell you this has to be one of the best places. they have made EVERY dish very different from other taquerias.

the prices are awesome and the horchata is bomb.

the neighborhood is hella sketchy but just don't make eye contact and have your running shoes on to be safe.

other than that man its bomb
author: Jaime D.

description:
Taiwan is not like other exotic Mexican cuisine generally like to have some rather special ingredients are produced, the other part is such dishes attracted certain ethnic groups like, therefore, have the opportunity to try this, it is excited very happy.
Point super burrito. Yes !!! oversized one. But unfortunately I did not choose spicy. But the rich avocado plus cheese and chicken. Let me full of happiness. And satiety throughout the day ... Oh my God !!
author: Mei L.

description:
I'm writing this review as a Nebraskan having visiting San Francisco on vacation - I know San Franciscans take tacos and burritos pretty seriously, so take my review with a grain of salt (although I have lived in both Southern California and Southern Arizona, so I've had good Mexican food...)

We were staying near Taqueria Cancun during our visit and needed somewhere to grab a quick, inexpensive dinner before our drinks reservation later that evening. Our Airbnb host mentioned the taqueria down the street that we figured would work out just fine. It's a hole-in-the-wall kind of place, but sometimes that's just where to find the best food, ya know? We really enjoyed our food here, both ordering a carne asada super taco, which was only a few bucks and one was plenty big for a late meal before going out. Not many places to sit, but we lucked out since we came during a non-meal time. Friendly service, too.
author: Hollyanne F.

description:
I have to say, I'm a little concerned by what some other Yelpers are saying: terrible health score and that their rice is cooked in chicken fat, rending their "vegetarian" burrito a flour-wrapped lie. 

But I've never been disappointed here in the taste department, and I'm no stranger to Bay Area burritos. The fact that sour cream and a generous portion of avocado come standard on any burrito makes it a winner in my book. 

The interior is gross, which you'd expect around Mid-Market. So don't go expecting to feel comfortable sitting down or anything. However, it's a solid to-go burrito that won't leave you hungry.
author: Charles R.

description: I didn't find this place to hold up to its yelp reviews (some of you fooled me). In my opinion the price did not match the flavor.The food is bland, soggy, and the hot sauce is not fire.  I'm not much for quantity but more about the quality and taste. SF doesn't have much options so I guess if you have some really (really) huge cravings, go here.
author: Anu C.

description:
OMG. I just ate a baby!
 
Ok, so maybe not exactly...but I just consumed a breakfast burrito that was twice the size of one of Paris Hilton's pups (not THOSE pups-stop that).  This thing was a monster. A delicious monster stuffed with scrambled eggs, chorizo sausage, rice, cheese, sour cream and fresh avocados.  When I bit in, I was impressed to find that the contents were well distributed throughout the burrito.  No lopsidedness here. No sir. 

They actually had a good selection of Jarritos soda flavors. Is it me, or does soda always taste better out of a glass bottle? 

I stared at the "interesting" mural on the wall as I sipped my pina soda.  The mermaids painted were not of the Ariel/Little Mermaid variety. They were more of the tranny variety. Hey - more power!

Overall, a fabulous burrito in a no-frills taqueria. 

Now please excuse me...I feel as though I'm about to give birth.
author: Tara L.

description: I've been eating here for many many years. The food has ALWAYS been amazing and remains AMAZING!!!! I eat the steak and shrimp nachos but I also eat the wet buritto steak and shrimp of course. I love the flavors the prices are VERY reasonable. I live in San Leandro and I travel to the city often simply for Taqueria Cancun. 10 stars if I could!!!
author: Mocha M.

description:
Dear Taqueria Cancun,

Thanks to you, I now know what FRESH, AMAZING fast Mexican food tastes like, and how it can change your very being. Thanks to you, it will be next to impossible to find anything half as good in my Canadian lands. Your Super Taco changed my life. I will now forever roam the streets of Calgary, Montreal and everywhere in between in search of a Super Taco as stupendous as yours. The meat, the toppings, the avocado... I still dream of that time I took a bite into it and realized what I had been missing all these years. So what if you are located next to a grubby street corner that injects fear into the hearts of wide-eyed Canadians like myself? For you I will brave any dirty grubby street because I know what awaits me at the end of the tunnel... your Super Taco, like a shining beacon of light. 

Pardon me if I was overly poetic and emotional. But that is what your tacos bring out in me. I have now been converted.. into an unstoppable poet who just discovered the joys of Taqueria Cancun and the treasures it holds.

I cannot wait for the next time we meet. 

Love and yearning,
S


21/30
author: Sab N.

description:
Sums up the place after a day of having to walk down the area that is infested with any goon that you can think of on your own adventure. Asides that I've checked into this spot a few times and ordered a Super Quesadilla. Everything here is made to order and it won't really break your pocket when you are in a jam. I highly recommend this place when you are out and about and when you are in need of that easy to afford spanish/mexican food that everybody likes. I haven't gone in for the rolled tacos but for every time that I have paid a visit here I would get a Super Quesadilla with a different choice meat every time. Drinks and stuff are about as average as any taqueria that you would find in the city. The place is small but you can fit quite a number of people at this location when you are out and about with a friend or two. Oh yeah btw never pass on the spicy salsa... its requisimo :D


Have fun hunting guys!!!
author: Xeirhen V.

description:
High risk.

Food inspection score is 73: http://www.sfdph.org/dph/EH/Food/score/default.asp

Decided to go for it and let a day pass before yelping my (splash of oil) grilled chicken, black beans and salsa on a (no other options) flour tortilla time to settle.

Settled fine. Admit the burrito was large and good. $6 just gets you healthier options elsewhere. With less risk.
author: Jason B.

description: it's funny reading all of these reviews on this rat hole.  this taqueria is GROSS!  filthy inside, sketchy people outside, and below average mexican food.  It makes me thankful I live in Oakland where delicious, real mexican food can be found.
author: Mara D.

description: Divey, but good burritos on a scary stretch of Market St.   I got a grilled chicken super burrito - it was huge.  Lots of rice, but it was tasty rice...   Chips were average at best.   I'd go back.
author: Dave C.

description: Not as good as the other Taqueria Cancun and they don't open early enough to serve breakfast despite serving breakfast burritos. The inconsistency baffles.
author: Misha T.

description:
Great tacos in a good location downtown. I had pastor and carnitas, both very tasty and I got transported back to mex for a second. At 2.65$ each, and the have sangria soda.

The place is smallish and very simple, the five stars are for the food and the good price. We'll be back :)
author: Krito R.

description:
Made me and my friend sick! I'm don't usually care about cheap/simple restaurants, but this one looked dirty and the food made me and my friend sick. Plus, there were customers with dogs inside.

For good price I've been to better Mexican places.
author: Gus O.

description:
So I was told that I had to get a burrito before my San Francisco vacation came to a close, despite the fact that I really wanted a cheeseburger that night. We went to Taqueria Cancun around 8 pm on a Saturday and there was a long line, but I was told it wasn't as long as it could get! I ordered the super burrito with chicken, cheese, salsa, sour cream, but I didn't get rice or beans because I'm not a fan. The burrito was giant! There was no way I could have eaten it in one sitting. I liked it, but I wasn't blown away. I thought it could have used more cheese and sour cream. 

As for the place itself, it was packed. We had to squeeze at the end of a table and it was hard to eat. It's also very loud. If you're ok with that and love burritos, this is your place. Overall, not bad, but not my favorite spot.
author: Maryclaire H.

description: Although this place is located in the sketchy neighborhood , I think it is one of my favorite  spots.... I always order their super burrito with grilled steak - and  never get disappointed. Its fresh, tasty, and filling ...Their chips and salsa are great too ...
author: George B.

description:
I ordered a taco salad with beef and it came filled with a generous amount of meat & cheese over lettuce and had fresh avocado on top

it was a filling & satisfying meal, the service is very fast, but the serving of chips & salsa was very minimal and the cups for salsa are tiny, cost extra for more chips, not the usual help yourself all you can eat salsa bar most nicer taquerias have, the chips were also harder than usual and not fresh and crisp like they should be

it's good, but Ive had better, this is definitely not a good place to take the family, too cramped inside with minimal seating, no rest rooms either

I also noticed the Health Dept score card posted inside was ranked at 83 percent
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: Poor health score, small serving of tough chewy meat, and over salted food. I had an upset stomach after eating here.
author: Nina M.

description:
My ass they have the Best Veggie Burrito in the Bay.
They have NO veggie burrito because the rice is made with chicken stock.
What the F? 
Yelp claims "vegetarians go nuts for this spot" probably because they don't know they're eating chicken.
LAME.
author: Crystal N.

description: The worst food i have had since i moved to SF.. truely awful shit.. stay away at all costs.. disguted by what i was given
author: Jack O.

description: A San Francisco staple. Cheap, flavorfull Mexican food. I love the nachos the most and the salsas are so delicious. The staff is nice too!
author: Pamela G.

description:
food here is prettygood, cheap, and quick, ive been here 10+ times because im living closeby. i always order to go but they do have seating. these guys need a real restaurant, much respect, please tip them if you have the money

Victors and Taqueria El Sol are my new favorite place to eat, but this is as good as it gets for a small shop in the TL
author: Cara D.

description:
My co-worker and I walked all the way from the Fairmont Hotel to this place on 6th and Market. I kind of wonder if you aren't Hispanic if the cooks hate on your burrito ( not very much meat)?

Well my friend and I both ordered carne asada super burritos with black beans, minus sour cream. These burritos were packed with meat and a everything else a super comes with especially fresh avocado. We all know crackhead 6th street but there were a ton of suits in here just like ourselves and the food never ever fails to impress.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
Market street can be a scary place for someone who is not used to homeless people collapsing in the middle of the street. This place fits in well by its looks, dont expect to find anything fancy in here. Even just fining a place to sit can be a challenge cause its busy most of the time. I went for the burrito that is supposed to be one of SFs finest. It took them a while to make it, I already thought they had forgotten about my order. The food was worth the wait though: the portion is gigantic and impossible to finish even for a strong eater, also due to the massive amount of cheese and sauce the burrito swims in. Not a healthy choice of dinner, but a tasty one, and at little over 6$ definitely a bargain.

What else is there to say? Oh yeah, they have Mexican sodas for 1,80$, I didnt try them but they look quit exciting.
author: Andreas R.

description:
First off, if Mr. Bob B's photo doesn't capture the essence of this neighborhood in an achingly beautiful yet painful way, well, you haven't spent enough time in this neighborhood.

But enough about people face planting on sidewalks and spending the day there...

Cancun is not my favorite burrito joint in the city, but for the area it's the tops.

Truth be told, lately I'm partial to the quesadilla, which is compromised of a serious mound of cheese cooked inside a gargantuan flour tortilla. No care whatsoever goes into spreading out the cheese - so it's all piled up like Mt. McDairy in the middle - and there's nothing to it but cheese and tortilla, but add some of the accompanying salsa and it's a helluva treat for $3.50 or some such.

The burritos are generously sized and they make some outstanding beans (I've been known to order nothing but beans from time to time, which makes me a weirdo: I realize this.) The guys working there are nice, you get free chips with pretty much everything and they don't make horchata. Ever.
That's actually sad news, as I love horchata, but if more of us start asking perhaps they'll catch on and deliver some of that sweet white nectar we crave.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
There are so many hole in the wall Mexican restaurant in San Francisco.  I can't say anything really stands out about Taqueria Cancun.  But if you find yourself nearby and want a fix, you could certainly do much worse.

I had the Alhambra Especial (meat plate).  It was pretty tasty and came with all the usual fixin's.  I enjoyed it.  The guys working there were nice and friendly.

If I was in the neighborhood, I would not hesitate to go back.
author: Mark D.

description: This place is right across from my new office building and I must say it's pretty legit.  It's not super expensive, you get chips and salsa with your order and the super burrito is really good.  I'll be back for sure.
author: Blake B.

description: I'm going to update this because I got over the missing meat in my burrito last time. And anyway, people make mistakes. Truthfully, the few times I've been there, the food is good and fair priced.
author: Opal L.

description: CASH ONLY, they can get busy during the lunch hours but in this hood options are limited and the food is always fresh.
author: Magda G.

description:
Bad decision jeans in burrito form. I don't know what it is. I can't find Mexican food to suit my palate in SF. I know, I know... it sounds weird. But, it's true. And, before you start belly achin' that I don't know nothin' in fly over country, I'd like to add that Chicago Mexican food is pretty legit. SF? Meh. I've had better.

Yes, the burrito is big. But as someone said (but *not* to me), size isn't everything. Midway through eating my chicken burrito, I wondered why I was doing so. I was laboring through the wrap, alternating between green and red sauce with each bite and I didn't know why. It was filling. But, it wasn't very good. It was a chore to eat it. But for my inability to throw away food, I would have tossed the bugger. In fact, it wasn't very memorable... until the heartburn. That, I have memories of. Maybe I just haven't met the right SF burrito. Or, maybe, I was born this way. Who knows. 

Points for the Mexican Coke. That's always worth a star.
author: Johnny T.

description:
Most cuisines taste better when prepared in proper, clean establishments, and some are just better when the place is grungy, open late, served by surly dudes, and in a rough neighborhoods. Burritos are one such food. It's the best burrito joint in SoMa, and not needing to run to the Mission for a fix is a Dog-send.

If you have a craving and your Clipper card's empty, check out Taqueria Cancun for one tasty burrito!
author: Kevin B.

description:
By far, my FAVORITE Mexican food spot in San Francisco and my favorite out of the  Taqueria Cancun chain.

It may not be the most hip scene, and yes they are cash only. But the food and service here are both equally amazing. I come in here and I know I'm going to leave with an amazing dish of food and no attitude with it.
author: Trav M.

description:
I just kind of realized coming here was a bad decision. OH WELL. 

I split a super veggie burrito with DJTINACHRISTINA as we made our way home (where everything literally broke loose and we ended up on the roof and in our neighbors apt for an hour and OMG THEY ARE FRENCH. WE LIVE WITH FRENCH DUDES NOW.) 

But the burrito was good. Better than I didn't remember. But I remember this one. Kind of. Eh. 3 stars.
author: Emily D.

description:
I've lived in this neighborhood for years and have grown accustomed to the colorful scene on 6th and Market.  So my rating has nothing to do with the ambiance. Just the menu labeling.  

If this place offered an actual vegetarian burrito, I'd eat here all the time.

My gripe for this place is a gripe I have for 90% of the taquerias in this town.  Don't call a burrito a "veggie" burrito or a "vegetarian" burrito if it's filled with lard and chicken stock.  I know a lot of people prefer burritos with that stuff as it makes the food admittedly more authentic, but this is SF and I think people have a right to know if things are actually vegetarian or not.

So vegetarians take note: when they say it's the best "veggie" burrito in SF, they mean the best veggie burrito for meat eaters.  I'll stick to the non-authentic but actual vegetarian-friendly places, muchas gracias.
author: J K.

description:
I visited this place on my first trip to San Fran 5 years ago and haven't been able to get the vegetarian burrito out of my daydreams. I went back last year and it was every bit as good. 
They give you two kinds of salsa with chips while you wait. 
It's totally sketchy, but you'll have stories about the guy who came in and tried to sell you underwear.
author: J B.

description:
I was in San Fran a week and the fact that I ate here twice tells you how good it is. You know you've found burrito bliss in SF when San Diegans are 5 staring it. The carne asada was about as much fun to eat as a wet T-shirt contest on a college holiday. 

It's tiny, dingy, and has no public restroom...The type of joint that when you enter you just know you're in for a some top quality comfort Mex. The only thing that would be nice is if they had better chips, because the ones they currently serve are similar to store bought. Even with this tiny flaw Taqueria Cancun gets the San Diego seal of approval. 

If you haven't tried it yet, get there! Cancun is like a spring break trip for your taste buds only even better cuz there's way less of a chance of contracting a venereal disease.
author: Danny W.

description:
This joint will hold a special place in my heart and stomach as the first place I got some food in SF. I was starving and needless to say it was late so my options were limited. It's been a while since I've had Mexican... real Mexican anyways. So I order the super quesadilla with chorizo minus the sour cream for here. The guy at the counter gave me some chips and salsa/guac and I have a seat. 

Sure this place (and most places in Union Square) is a hole in the wall dive but damn that was some good chips. A bunch of people had just left before I started eating and it was late so it wasn't that busy. I was mildly entertained by the number of bums who tried to jack some left over chips by some people who left. But I soon came to realize that's what the bums in San Francisco do. 

When my quesadilla was ready it was huge and not quesadilla shape but for the amount of things stuffed into it, chorizo, avocado, cheese, and salsa it'd be hard to put all those ingredients in there and not have it just fall through the tortilla. I never had such a delicious thing before. And these guys don't skimp on the ingredients. Every bite was packed full of meat and cheesy goodness. Whatever fell out I scooped up with my leftover chips. I think the meal ran me $7-8 bucks but I left there feeling both stuffed and satisfied I definitely got my monies worth.
author: Michelle J.

description:
I was seduced by the name as I've eaten at the Taqueria Cancun in the Mission multiple times. This one seemingly has no connection aside from the prices. 
I ordered a Carne Asada burrito with half black beans and half refried beans, and got pure gristle - no exaggeration, not a single piece of meat, and pinto beans.
If I had paid more than six dollars for this, I would have been more angry.
The complete lack of meat in a meat burrito, especially when meat and beans were the only two ingredients IN my burrito, seems suspect, but what can you do? 
Leave a bad yelp review, I guess.
author: D C.

description:
I almost forgot I ate here.... hmm, maybe because it was a semi-intoxicated '4th meal'? Yep, I'm not ashamed to admit I'll squeeze in a burrito whenever I can. And Taqueria Cancun was definitely worth the almost-mile hike in high heels! (now WHY did we walk again?).

The insides are definitely not 'Mexi-chic', but they'll do. You'll wait a little longer than you're used to for a taco and such, too. However, once I got back to my hotel room and took advantage of my burrito, the wait was validated. The burrito was crammed with super tender, well-seasoned carne asada, rice, beans, cheese, sour cream and plenty of guacamole. No skimping here, not at all. And, Taqueria Cancun is very inexpensive, even by non-San Francisco standards.

Oh, and I ate every last bite. Please don't ever challenge an Eastern European hearty appetite. You WILL lose!
author: Jelena Z.

description: My favorite Mission Taqueria and this ones right in the heart of the remainder of mid-market. The setting is crazy as some others have remarked. If you understand and appreciate where you are and don't get overly freaked out. The super veggie burrito is the real deal as is the carnitas. Beats both Farolito and La Taqueria in my book. More flavor and way more messy.
author: Jason O.

description:
5 stars for the price
2 stars for the flavor.  

I had a burrito mojado and although it was huge and the price was more than reasonable ($5.99), I've had better.  The flavor was not there.  Very bland.

And just so you know, the menu shown in the photo section does show Beer,  the cashier guy told me tonight they don't serve alcohol anymore.
author: David S.

description: One word- yum! Super fresh, fast and tasty. We had the carnitas super tacos. They came with plenty of fresh avocado. The meat was delicious.
author: Sarah K.

description:
My Go-to place !

Prices are reasonable, The food is delicious.

I always order the Super Chicken Burrito.

Fills me up.

The only downfall is the size of this restaurant, but the food outshines the size.
author: Denisha D.

description:
Can be a sketchy area, my bike was nearly stolen from right across the street but their food is fantastic. No frills service, but grab a super burrito Al pastor and you can't go wrong. Drunk or sober, great mexican food.

One negative is the occasional patron who is on drugs/inebriated but it adds to the whole scene. Fun place to grab a bite.
author: John S.

description: You can't call it a "veggie" burrito if its loaded with chicken stock. Thats unacceptable.
author: Jason S.

description: Good carnitas burrito. Simple and tasty. Could have used more salsa. Will try super next time.
author: Anthony P.

description: We've been coming here for 25 years. Always liked the food. Love the carne asada plates. Don't know why people are rating so low. Sometimes the outside crowd can be noisy. Only negative thing i can say is that the price has risen substantially, but that can be said of anything 25 years later.
author: Mary R.

description: Another great meal here...I had a Torta, which was cooked to perfection with lots of refried beans, grilled chicken and cheese.  It's amazing that something so simple can be so good.
author: Ken G.

description:
Easily the absolute best burrito I've had in San Francisco so far. The service was quick, the price was great (7 bucks after tax for a super with chips and guacamole!), and the food is outstanding.

The place itself is rather small, and I've taken off a star for the unfortunate lack of a salsa bar. They did give me salsas with my chips though, some of their incredibly flavorful pico and definitely not enough of their delicious guacamole/avocado salsa (because tbh I can't tell which one this is). I hope they'll give me more next time, cuz I'm definitely going back.

As far as the burrito's concerned, the meat was tender and really flavorful and there was TONS of it! The beans were delicious and it was rather huge - as it should be. Totally going again. You won't be disappointed.
author: Ellie M.

description:
How does this place have 4 solid stars?  I trusted you, Yelpers, and was severely let down.  "4 stars?", I thought, "it must be really good!  I will just ignore this clearly displayed health inspection score card of only 82."

I have literally never had a burrito this bad before.  I ordered a regular pollo burrito.  It was dry.  SO DRY.  The tortilla tasted old like it had been left out all week, the chicken was dry and flavorless, the rice was dry and hard like when you leave it uncovered in the fridge for a week, and even when I put salsa on each bite the food would scrape down my throat; I could barely swallow.  I had to go buy a $5 lemonade from a booth at the nearby asian heritage festival to wash the bad out.

Now, I am not one to waste food (I can EAT) but I tossed a fist sized portion of the burrito in the garbage.

I am going to stay away from burritos for a while because the burrito here turned me off so much.

Also, I'm not just being dramatic, my boyfriend's breakfast burrito sucked, too.
author: Light Bulb J.

description:
This place is bomb diggity! I go here regularly because it is the epitome of hole-in-the-wall SF Mexican goodness. I always get the Mojado Burrito (wet burrito). The ingredients are fresh, the salsa is tasty and spicy enough, and the meat is flavorful. And it is super affordable! The Mojado comes out to $7.34 after taxes. The only thing about it is that it is cash only. But that is typical of small taquerias anyway.

I highly recommend you try this place and see for yourself how good it is!
author: Mike F.

description:
This is a tiny place in an area that's gets close to being sketchy. I usually get their Al Pastor; great flavor. Chips are ok, salsa is ok. But the food is pretty tasty. Great prices too.

I should try their tacos sometime. 

Overall thoughts : Cheap, fast and good.
author: Stephanie K.

description: I come here every other week for lunch, sometimes breakfast. In the past I've had the chorizo con huevos, tacos and burritos and I can honestly say its all been really good.
author: James M.

description:
Despite the decidedly off-putting first picture that yelp has for this place (the homeless people in front of the restaurant), and despite the fact that this picture is 100% accurate for 90% of the time in front of this place, do yourself a favor: hide your valuables, brave this rather shady area of the city, sidle past the homeless people, bring some cash (it's cash-only), and get some food at Taqueria Cancun. To go, of course. Don't sit in there. I'm told that people sometimes get hassled by the local flavor for money while sitting in the place. 

Yes, it is not the cleanest looking place. In fact, it is probably one of the dirtiest looking places that I continue to frequent. Dirty in appearance only- I've never had problems with the food. The smell of the cooking meats as I walk by the place drown out the less pleasant smells in the 6th and Market area. The meat smells downright amazing. 

I've had a few things here. Most often either the burrito mojado (wetback burrito) with carne asada or the super tacos with carne asada. As you can see, I love the carne asada here. I love carne asada in general, but especially here. It's perfectly seasoned and perfectly cooked and perfectly cut up. It really is perfect. I've gotten carnitas once, having succumbed to the peer pressure of people constantly talking up carnitas as a general matter. But I actually don't love pork, aside from bacon. The carnitas were not bad, and if they're your thing, you'll probably like it. But as for me, it needs to just be all carne asada all the time. 

The first time I ordered the burrito mojado, I looked at the sign and thought it was a joke. Seriously, wetback burrito? Isn't wetback a derogatory term? I was very uncomfortable with saying "I'll have the wetback burrito" so instead I just said "I'll have the burrito mojado," but in confirming with me, they said in English "oh, the wetback burrito?" I was taken aback, but it seems like they have a sense of humor about this sort of thing, so I like it. Anyhow, the burrito mojado is huge and deliciousness. The beans, rice, sour cream, cheese, meat, guac all go together perfectly. I daresay it is like a symphony of flavors. I usually turn it into two meals nowadays, forcing myself to stop at a reasonable point rather than try to fit the whole thing in my stomach. That I cannot fit this entire burrito into my stomach in one sitting is one of my greatest life failures. 

The super tacos are essentially the burrito mojado in an open, smaller form. They're also huge. I usually will just get one if I'm not too hungry, and will get two if I am hungry but usually can only get comfortably to 1.5 super tacos. 

The food is super cheap. The burrito mojado is about $6 and the super tacos are about $3 each. 

From time to time, they have horchata. All Mexican restaurants should have horchata. Horchata is the best! They also have the strawberry Jarritos, which is my favorite one. Though lately, I haven't seen the strawberry one, which makes me sad as I really love it. 

Two things I don't like about this place. They don't make their own chips- the tortilla chips are store-bought. I also don't like the red salsa that they give with the complimentary chips. They give a little container of red salsa and a little one of green salsa. The green salsa is fantastic and I would drink it if it were socially acceptable to drink salsa. The red kinda looks like tomatoes that have been sitting around and out in the open for a while. Kinda tastes that way too...  They're happy to give you more salsa if you request it though. 

The staff are so genuinely nice and friendly. The wait is never too long for the food once you've ordered, though sometimes there is a significant line during peak lunch times. 

Definitely my go-to Mexican place in the city.
author: Jia min C.

description: Fantastic burritos, my ideal hole in the wall taqueria.  Why?  Because their burritos are excellent and cheap!  They grill your tortilla (not your standard warm-up) to a perfect crispy texture, melting the cheese to the right amount.  Excellent beans/rice, salsa, and fresh cut onions which adds a magic crunch to each bite.  Don't let the decor fool you, these guys are specialists!
author: Morgan R.

description:
I live in downtown and when I heard there was a Taq Cancun in my area I was so excited, until I walked there. You can't drive, but you can take muni to right in front of the place.

Food is really good. Staff is nice, but not too friendly. I think its just the area. You've got to put your guard up, if not just a little bit.

Their food is just as good as the other location, but I like the mission location because of the seating- much bigger.
author: Ash R.

description:
The best veggie burrito in SF. 
The other Cancuns are OK but the master twisters are downtown. 
It's the worst 'hood in The City and there's no where to park, you would never walk in this dump if you weren't hep.  I will not take off a star for their circumstances.
author: Richard L. D.

description:
Four stars summed up easily in four words: carne asada super burrito.

I could surely stop there.

But you know what, Taqueria Cancun? There's just one more thing I feel I must say: if your chips weren't so utterly lame, I've have tacked on that elusive fifth star. Pairing such tasteless triangles with a burrito as positively piquant as this ought to be criminal.
author: Miriam W.

description: There was an era where I use to eat burritos morning to midnight, from breakfast to passing out in & on them after midnight. Now though, I've paired it down & grab a burrito before I head home some nights, and for being under $6, out in 3 minutes, if I'm going to eat the official forearm of the fattest nation in the world (Mexico), it may as well be this dive. The traditional al pastor is better than 95% of where you're trying to go in the Mission.
author: Jon A.

description:
The Super Breakfast Burrito...DAMN. Filled with chorizo, eggs, guacamole, sour cream, cheese...it is a disgusting, unhealthily delicious amount of food to eat in the morning. 

This burrito is so big that when I put it down it stood up on its own. So I ate it like George from Rampage eats buildings.* I didn't even use my hands.

Huh. When you write that down, it sounds kind of gross, In fact, I'm thoroughly ashamed of myself.
______

*OK, so he just smashed buildings, he didn't eat them. But I came flying in on a blimp, and bashed passing helicopters just because I could. So there ARE similarities.
author: Peter D.

description: Standard burrito place in SF.  The branch in the Mission is better, but this place is still good if you in this part of the town.
author: Ben L.

description: this place smells like sewage. this is definitely unsanitary and could make you sick to tour stomach.  do not go there.
author: Pete S.

description: Great burritos.  I've always been impressed with their prawn burrito.  They always cook it just right and stuff it full.
author: Kory-Oren E.

description:
Hi tourists!

If you don't want to venture down to the Mission (or other, unnamed locations) for a proper taqueria, this place will more than do to introduce you to San-Francisco-style Mexican. The staff that works this place are arguably the best crew running a taqueria in the city.

And if you're wondering why there seems to be a bunch of hipsters in there, it's because there's a band rehearsal warehouse around the way.

You'll love the "grit" of the neighborhood, too.  It'll make you feel like home.
author: Jim S.

description:
Their carne asada super burrito was hands down the best burrito I've ever tasted. I think of all the great mexican places to be found in san francisco, this sketchy-looking diamond in the rough has really set a new standard and perhaps spoiled me forever!

The burrito was fluffy, warm and high-quality dough, not the crap they use at a lot of the chain places.
