The carne asada was richly seasoned and very flavorful, with just a bit of crunchy zest in all the right places. Best of all is the guacamole, which is truly top-shelf! Rich, thick slices of avocado cushion this little heavenly brick of a burrito in every bite.

Comes with chips and salsa, and only $6.50 for all that? Sold! Please note, like a lot of the divey places in central SF, they are cash-only.

A must-try if you are anywhere near civic center or union square.
author: David P.

description:
Bless the hands that create such a wonderful veggie burrito.   The rice is so fluffy, pintos are perfectly tender, fresh cuts of avocado, some queso and the right kind of stretchy tortilla.  Rest assured that the quality is high, and the excellence is consistent.  I've eaten this burrito too many times for it to be a fluke.

Cancun is also great if you're having friends over.  I asked the owner if I should put in an order for 20 veggie burritos the day before, he told me to just come in and order them when I was ready.  The next day I dropped by with a backpack and 20 minutes later, 20 burritos with chips and salsa.  Amazingly fast, consistently delicious!!!
author: Christopher K.

description: Solid No Thrills Burrito Shop!  They have two kinds of salsa which are both tasty and spicy.  Best addition to the burritos here is the freshly sliced avocado.  This has turned into one of my go to spots for takeout on the way home from work.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
These guys are the Soup Nazis of tacos.

If you can put up with them screwing up your order (seriously, you wrote "No sour cream" on the ticket, you handed it to the guy who put sour cream on the taco), them not letting you order after 11:30 pm, the really crazy/ really dirty homeless people in there with you (sure, judge me, but you know it bothers you, too), you'll be treated to some pretty good mesican food.  They put fresh avocados on just about everything, huge plus in my book.
author: Mike D.

description: Common now Cancun, you guys used to hook a hermano gringo up in terms of quantity... The past 3 times I've came in, that quantity wasn't up to par. Maybe for someone with a decent appetite but common now, I'm 6'4 and you can't throw a little more pollo up in that burrito??? You guys still do have THE best salsa verde on the face of the planet so I refuse to give you any lower than 3 stars.
author: Patrick O.

description:
No trip to Pearl Art Supply is complete without a detour into Taqueria Cancun on the next block.

Narrow and grimy, yes, but strangely inviting, with cracked mirrors offset by bright walls. And if you're a girl in need of an ego boost, the guys hanging around outside are always at the ready with a "Hey, sweetheart!" or "Where ya goin', pretty lady?"

Now for the burritos. The flavor is all there, but I have a complaint: They fall apart as you eat them. At other places the burritos are nicely cohesive and remain intact as you unwrap the foil and work your way down. These spill their contents all over the place and make a big mess...even the super burritos. You'd think all that sour cream would hold everything together like glue but it doesn't.

Anyhow, they still merit an "A-OK" rating. I'll be back!
author: Valeria R.

description: One word - YUM!  whenever my coworkers are craving a great burrito, we make the trek to this place!  The place is small but they make great burritos.  I agree with the person who wrote you don't see tourists in this place.  Which makes it an even better place to grab lunch!  It's in a shady part of the city so I will only go here with a group but definitely a tasty lunch.
author: Amanda K.

description: I like getting the veggie burritos here. I'm not a big fan of Mexican food, but I would come here when I want some. It's huge and the price is good.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
To some people, "San Francisco charm" means picturesque views of the Golden Gate Bridge, Rice-a-roni, cable cars, and the rest of the touristy bullshit.

To others, it means vagrants yelling at each other, clutching your purse as you hurriedly walk through, and shantytowns made of cardboard boxes.  

As you walk down the seedier part of Market, SF charm - the latter - is in full effect.  But as you approach Taqueria Cancun, shattered dreams and the smell of dried piss give way to an oasis of fine Mexican dining (to clarify, by "fine" I mean served wrapped in foil).  

For $6, you can get a burrito mojado - a large burrito covered in enchilada sauce and cheese (my favorite) - or any of the various other items you'd expect at any other of the various taquerias around the city. They're all good.

What sets Taqueria Cancun apart is the meat.  Unlike most other places, it isn't sitting in a bath of brine or whatever until you order.  When it comes to Mexican food, there's nothing worse than a burrito dripping from not sauce, but water.  That shit is just gross.  Here, they scoop it out, throw it onto the grill for a bit, and then assemble your burrito.  And the avocado: it's fresh - you can actually watch them cut the avocado and scoop it into your burrito - and not some goop that they squirt out of a bottle.

While I still think L.A. Mexican food is the best in California, Taqueria Cancun is my go-to spot in SF.
author: Gary L.

description:
Taqueria Cancun has amazing tacos, burritos, quesadillas, and NACHOS! If you don't mind the crazies outside, possible shootings, and ambulances passing by every hour, this is definitely your place. If you come here, just don't stare at anyone around you, the crazies here are like zombies and will most likely follow you. It's nice to have a Taqueria Cancun on Market, saves some time from going all the way to the Mission. 

I have a love-hate relationship with Cancun. I came here with my coworkers and the ATM ripped me off. It never gave me cash or a receipt. So I spoke in Spanish with one of the workers and he told me "you deal with the machine" (in spanish), and pretty much shooing me away. The other worker was very nice, tried to help, and gave me a phone number to call. The taqueria has nothing to do with the machines, but they do get paid for having one in there, so I was disappointed they did not care. My friend was nice enough to buy me a quesadilla and needless to say, it was amazing and only $6. If I ever come back, I will take it to go.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
This place is bad but I still go a half dozen times a year.  

I only can eat the chicken because the steak is so filled with Gristle that it makes it uneatable the majority of the time. The vegetarian is OK.

If your going to take the risk I highly recommend kicking up your threat level one more notch by coming here on a Friday night after 9PM. because this is when all the freaks from the SOMA and TL decide to come in and either try to sell me their stolen watches or beg for change. It's worth the price of admission just for the entertainment value.  One night there was a homeless man blocking the exit to the front door demanding money from patrons exiting. He was there for a good five to seven minutes while the employees got him to move on. Why would you go anyplace else? 

Health Card = 94
author: Justin S.

description:
The food is great, the location is shit. So really, if you're willing to overlook the fact that the streets smell like urine and you have to fear for your safety on your way there, I'd recommend it. 

As for the food, I had a chicken super burrito with avacado. The chicken was amazing, it had such an authentic taste. The burrito was huge, which probably wasn't good because i was convinced i could finish it...I 100% recommend trying it. Prices were very reasonable, and service was quick, although they dont take cards, so have cash ready. 

The restraunt itself was the size of a closet. We were sitting next to the sink where they washed the dishes, so that was a little off-putting. Another thing is theres no parking, but that's pretty normal for SF. There's a $10 parking lot around the croner (i think that was the price)

Overall, I would like to try one of the other locations, just because that was literally the only reason this is a 3 star.
author: Alyssa L.

description:
DO NOT BE FOOLED BY THE OUTSIDE OF THIS PLACE!!!

There is nothing much I love in this world more than a good burrito, and for that reason I've tried them all over SF.  I get a chicken burrito here every time I walk by with some cash in my pocket (like most small places its cash only), for my money Taqueria Cancun is the best in the city.

I do feel the need to mention this is not a review of the location (middle of the 'loin), the parking situation (literally as bad as it can be) or the cleanliness of the store (its a Burrito shop guys, they are not performing surgery), but simply a reflection of the tastiness of their burrito.

In the art of burrito manufacturing they hit all the major points: fluffy tortilla, don't skimp on the cheese and sour cream, fresh ingredients (chunks of avocados are a good thing right? lol) and chicken is perfectly cooked and seasoned.  If you don't believe me they have been on SF weekly's best burrito list since like the beginning of time, so for that alone its worth a trip.

Bottom line - if your not freaked out by the relatively harmless tenderloin, are in the area without a car and have cash in your pocket you are doing yourself a disservice by not eating here.  This place is over the top good

ps don't be fooled by the total stars, a lot of people have deducted (and not wrongfully) because of the location.  If it was just about the burrito, it'd be a four to 4.5 star spot easy
author: Andrew J.

description:
While this part of Market Street lacks some decent food stops, it's got one gem in the rough: Taqueria Cancun.

No longer do you have to make the trip into the Mission for this well-loved taqueria. Everything is right here just shy of downtown. They've got the super sized version of almost everything: super/nachos, super/quesadilla, super/tacos, and super/burrito. The wet burrito costs the same as  the super burrito and the veggie burrito costs as much as the meat burrito. Also on the menu are the torta, ceviche tostada, cocktail shrimp, and breakfast! I got the enchilda plate with carne asada. It came with some corn tortillas, rice, and refried beans. The beans were heaven, just the gooey kind where it's been so cooked that no beans were even discernable in the cheesy mess. I love mopping that stuff up with tortillas or chips. The rice was alright, maybe a little too wet and overcooked. The carne asada was great, but a little dry, which made it taste all the more meatier and made me like the red sauce all the more. The sour cream was the runny kind and on it laid a few large slices of yellow onion and tomato. The super burrito was good too, we got one with regular pollo. It was maybe even better the next day. All orders come with a basket of chips and 2 salsas. The salsas had kick in them, but wished they were less watery. The chips were super salty and coarse and definitely came from a bag.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Amazing food and reasonably priced. Fast great service and lively/friendly environment!
author: Danya G.

description: I always get the regular burrito with carnitas.  The meat is always great.  Sometimes there are little crispy pieces from the edges that add some nice texture.  Service is quick and friendly too.
author: Edward B.

description:
I'm scared...(pant)...(pant)

As I sprint on Market crossing the inevitable Sixth Street toward my place, I often buzz by this taqueria since my objective is to make every establishment a blur and every panhandler a missed acquaintance. But my friend insisted on satisfying his heartburn desire, so we entered this narrow eatery.

I wasn't even aware that its big brother in the Mission is such an acclaimed place for tacos and burritos, so I had a momentary delusion that this could be my undiscovered find for the month. But alas, not really...

I shared a Super Quesadilla - filled with meat, cheese, avocado and salsa - that was about $4, a good price for sure. But it turned out to be overcooked with burnt edges... perhaps it was an off night but my hopes were somewhat dashed. Not helping was the motley crew of regulars both behind and in front of the counter, none of whom attended dining etiquette school.

Perhaps I'll give it another try...when I feel like risking my safety for a few calories. Otherwise I may just have to fast....at least until I get to 7th Street.

FOOD - 2.5 stars...large enough portions and bargain priced...but quality was lacking for what is apparently known as a good taqueria
AMBIANCE - 1 star...I get nervous touching anything here (..but they proudly display the 9.5 rating they received from the health board)
SERVICE - 2 stars...order twice, eat once
TOTAL - 2 stars...afraid I need to venture further out for a good taqueria
author: Ed U.

description: Meh. The food was microwaved and not very good. Go elsewhere for a better burrito fix.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Simply one of the best Carnitas and Al Pastor i had the pleasure of putting in my mouth. The Big Burrito is a steal because it is a $5 Wet Burrito that comes with lots of meat, sauce, salsa, sour cream, and cheese and is huge! Their Super Burritos and Super Tacos are also definitely worth putting in your mouth because of the avacado they add on top of fully loading it up. 

There isn't a lot of seating so i usually come here for lunch and take it to go. They also have Coke in a glass bottle made with the real stuff! Nothing like authentic mexican food and an authentic bottle of Coke to wash it down.
author: Chris C.

description:
First day in town as an offical SF resident and hangry from a household goods search near Powell, we sought out lunch in the middle of tourist shopping hell. Thank goodness there was a Cancun nearby, thank goodness for their massive super nachos platter and juicy carnitas tacos. Satisfied, we got the heck out of Market and sauntered back to the new 'hood, recharged and refreshed thanks to the TC. 

PS, this location is so much better than the one on Mission St.
author: Angelina C.

description:
Been to both cancuns but I like the one on 6th better since I hang out with my cousins and they live near that area. The burritos are amazing. The super prawn burrito was super delicious. Other than that I usually order Al Pastor, steak or chicken. Friendly staff and pretty clean place too. 

Edit*

Just came back from Cancun today and had to bring it down a star. I ordered al pastor super with refried beans and extra cilantro and onions. As I was eating, I found random chilly peppers in my burrito. It became spicy and I ended up spending another 3 dollars on a large cantaloupe juice. Didn't expect to find that in my burrito.
author: Jasper N.

description:
The original and still the best has still got it.

No charges for chips. Loads of salsa. Fast. Dirty. Cheap. Good. 

Bonus for mad 'Loin-lads selling, pimping, or whatever the feck else they're doing coming in and out.
author: Glen M.

description:
Yesterday was day one of my diet and already I'm doing awesome! Headed over to Taqueria Cancun for a healthy burrito lunch: carne asada (protein), beans (protein), rice (vitamin c), sour cream (calcium), guacamole (vegetables), and cheese (omega-3s).

Rapid speed prep time adds to the positives, but on the downside, you won't find ample seating inside. Best bet would be to park your butt at a nearby park or bench. On a sunny afternoon, graze in Union Square whilst scarfing your Mexican torpedo. 

Best burrito outside of the Mission? Just maybe.
author: Monica S.

description: I wish I could give this place less than one star. Even the rats that live at taqueria cancun don't eat here.  Avoid this place
author: Mark K.

description:
Good, cheap burritos. Yeah, sure the crazies outside occasionally come inside to ask you for money while you eat (awkward), but it's ok. The food is good.

And, next time you're in this place, be sure to check out the mural. I mean, really, pay close attention. Don't those mermaids look like dudes to you?
author: Vanessa R.

description:
This is how all cheap joints should be. Fast, friendly and amazing Mexican fare. Really great cilantro salsa, too! Ambiance is nothing, but that's not why you go here. You go here for some damn delicious burritos, or, as in my case, taco salad. 

I adored their chips, too, but given the other reviews, maybe I'm alone on that one.
author: Olivia L.

description:
Wifey saw an ad that said that this place was voted "best burrito" 13-yrs in a row. I had my doubts. We foot it on over there as we walked past dudes smoking crack-rocks on the street corner, getting hit up by change every 20-ft, and having some old pimps look at me sideways as if me and the women Im with are trying to compete on they block. Naw Homie, just getting a burrito. 
Walked in and the inside of the restaurant is almost as rough as the outside. Usually this screams "authenticity!" to me, but I was disappointed. The Super burrito is a glorified "Burrito Supreme" from Taco Bell, but with a bit better meat. I like Burrito Supremes, so this wasnt a bad burrito, but not what I expected. Whoever voted this place "Best Burrito" has certainly never been to Southern California. If this is what NorCal has to offer for mexican food, they can keep it. 3 stars instead of 2 because of the large portions though.
author: Anthony A.

description: Good real Mexican food. Had a carne asada buritto, it was good and large portions.
author: Gabriel D.

description:
This place is awesome. They have the best burritos in the city. They have even won awards for them. 

They have many kinds of meat, quasadillas, and three different sizes in them and the burritos, super large burritos though. Every friend I've taken their has left saying it's was their new favorite burrito place.
author: Toby H.

description: I went to Taqueria Cancun and ordered a super chicken burrito. The size was good...I was able to cut it in half and eat it for two lunches! The chicken had a great seasoning on it which added a smokey/buffalo flavor to it which was very tasty.  I got take out and they give you chips and salsa. The green salsa was very yummy, but the red salsa tasted a little funny so I didn't eat it! However overall it was a good meal!
author: Heather S.

description:
I had a super steak taco and it was pretty damn good. Yes this place is tiny and somewhat dirty but hey.. my taco was da bomb. I also considered all the weirdos hanging around as free entertainment as I chowed down. I watched a lady bum have a spirited conversation with her imaginary friend the whole time and before I knew it my taco was gone. =)

Food : 8/10
Service : 5/10
Ambience : 5/10
author: Henry W.

description:
You basically have to earn your meal at Taqueria Cancun.  How do you earn it, you ask?  

You have to brave a scene of oddballs, the occasional domestic violence incident right outside their doors (which I witnessed this past week), an unacceptable 81 out of 100 on their Health Department cleanliness report, and literally rub elbows with sweaty neighborhood locals in a super-cramped space.

If you can do all that, you will be rewarded with one of the most flavorful burritos in the City at a bargain price.

Good Luck.
author: Don T.

description: My fave place to get Mexican in this area. It's Mexican so expect the portions to be huge and the prices to be budget-friendly. Everyone loves their burritos and I do too, but I prefer the quesadillas here. They're about the size of my head. Gluttony aside, I come here because the meat is done right: tender and full of flavor. Not the best in the city, but the best in the area...in my opinion.
author: Helen L.

description:
I have been living in NY for 8 years & immediately ending friendships with any CA native who utters 'there are no good burritos in this city.'  If taqueria cancun is what happens in california when I order a $6 take awayburrito in the middle of a dodgy neighborhood, can only imagine what would happen if I sought out a real dining experience.  Need to stop thinking about how many quality friendships I may have prematurely ended.

But back to the burrito.  It was so good.  Extremely greasy, but that met my expectations.  Everything was perfectly spread out.  Each bite contained a bit of charred carne asada, some creamy cheese/sour cream dairy delight, buttery rice, a little kick & a healthy dollop of avocado.  Threw away the chips because they just didn't look worthwhile.

I was like a little burrito-wielding refugee on the streets of SF.  Didn't want to eat in the establishment because the man next to me was letting his cat sit on his head.  Tried going outside to the street but two women in wheelchairs were having some sort of joust.  Thought of going to my hotel room, but knew the lasting smell of burrito would likely make me try to walk back to TC at some unsafe hour for round two.  Settled on the food court of the Westfield Mall down the street.  I could see all of the mall-goers with their food court fare eying me jealously.  Ok, that was probably a look of disgust rather than jealousy because i was eating this burrito like I was about to get kidnapped & locked up someplace where I would never see a burrito again.  Ever.
author: Talia R.

description:
The Burrito Mojado or "The Wet Back" (no joke, that's what it says on the sign) is excellent, as are the few other things I've tried.  The first taqueria I ever ate at in San Francisco was the Taqueria Cancun in the Mission.  Since then every time I've been back to the city some local tells me that the best burrito to be had is at El Toro, or some other mediocre taqueria.  Cancun is the best, seriously.  I live by the downtown location now, and it's fantastic.  Sure, it's cramped, and slightly dingy, but it's a taqueria, not The French Laundry.

Edit: I've moved away from the Burrito Mojado. The carnitas super burrito is amazing. Basically anything. You'll be thrilled.
author: Kendrick T.

description:
Thanks to Gareth for recommending this place.

I've only ordered one thing on the menu here, but it is so good that I can't seem to switch it up.  This place has the best carnitas I've ever tasted.  I always get the regular burrito (which is actually huge btw).  I think the total cost is about $6 and they throw in free chips and salsa.  Instead of cooking I should just order here everyday and save myself the time and money.

And yes this place is right near sixth street and not in the best part of town, but don't let that deter you.  You will be back if you give it a try.  I'm pretty excited to try the Carne Asada next.
author: Paul W.

description:
Quality may vary. 

Only eat here if you don't mind cockroaches. Seriously a friend took video of one running around where they prep the food, wish I could upload it here...

Also you might get a good price on a meal or you might get food poisoning with a side of dirty looks.

Beware of the rice, I'm pretty sure they don't keep track of how many hours (or even days)  its been sitting in the tray. = food poisoning.
author: Cat M.

description: The food is always very yummy here and they are very friendly, this is one of my favorite places to get Super Burrito or Burrito Mojado, absolutely love it!
author: Sakkara C.

description:
Simply, this the best burrito in San Francisco. I reccommend the vegetarian burrito with black beans. Don't forget to get extra green salsa!

It's just a little taqueria with limited seating, but that hardly matters. You might have to fend off some aggressive pan handlers to get to this location, but it's well worth it. Once, you're in the staff takes good care of you. They have more than one location, but this one does it the best.
author: Shannon P.

description:
This isn't my favorite of the three locations, but it's the closest to my house.  But the fact that it's in one of the worst neighborhoods in SF tells you how much I like this place!

Other locations are on Mission St (at 19th and past Cesar Chavez).

PROS:
- Open late
- Really affordable
- Not the fastest taqueria, but pretty quick
- Amazing salsa

CONS:
- No (safe) parking
- Not a place where you want to sit and eat
author: Drew P.

description:
You're GOING to have to brave the ridiculous, smelly, occasionally violent homeless people to get here. It's just fact. It's flipping Market & 6th. If you don't realize what you're getting into here, there's no way you can call yourself a resident of San Francisco.

That said, this place is tasty. Not the cheapest, but the quesadillas, burritos and tacos are all top notch. Absolutely perfect ingredient quality, proportion, and most importantly, distribution.
author: Andrew V.

description:
This place was pretty mediocre. Got a vegetarian burrito- the black bean option.  It was nice that there was more than one option to choose from for vegetarian burritos.  They offered re-fried beans as well as pinto beans as well.  We had been told that the burritos in San Francisco were huge, and this one was but it lacked flavor which was not made up by the large amount of food they gave us... The black beans were good but the rice was bland. 

Also got the melon agua fresca. Delicious! It was made with cantaloup. Highly recommended. 

This place was so packed with people we had to take our food to go. Not likely I'll ever be back. I've had better burritos in San Diego and LA.
author: Nathalie R.

description: The only reason they get one star it's because they gave me the food I paid for. But the burrito was horrible. A whole lotta bland beans and rice, very little meet (tongue that didn't have a good flavor) in comparison with "el farolito" burritos on mission. This place is garbage. Very disappointed... Rock on! ) ) d-.-b ( (
author: Amir A.

description: Just another taco shop. Nothing extraordinary. I had carnitas, lengua and pastor. All three were rather bland but they were much bigger than street tacos.
author: Henry P.

description:
Simply put, Taqueria Cancun is a tasty part of the Market Street scene. After discovering this little hole in the wall I gave up getting my burritos from the Mexican restaurant right across the street and instead walk the 2-3 blocks here. 

My favorite item on the menu is their Mojado Burrito. Nothing can beat a super burrito topped with spoonfuls of guac, sour cream and enchilada sauce. And for only $5.99? Insane.

Some might argue that Cancun is located in a shady part of downtown, by 6th and market. I've seen more than one violent disputes here but it doesn't take away from the food. If you think of it as part of the adventure, your Mexican cuisine will taste that much better.
author: Tim J.

description: Ordered a quesadilla with chicken and noticed that I forgot to ask for sour cream and avocado. Asked if I could add those ingredients and they said no. I was not happy - opened up the the quesadilla to find partially pink chicken and some napkins with blood on them WTF!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Francisco H.

description:
+1 star for the main photo for Cancun!

This place taste awesome! I don't know if it is because my senses are heightened every time I stroll on 6th st, ready to dodge all the vagrants that might pounce on me, but the packed house clearly shows that the trip here is worth it.

A super burrito here is about 6 bucks which is cheap. The meat is tasty and well cooked and they even use real avocado in it, not just some slimy goop other places does. 

The only thing I wish they had was a self serve salsa station. I never realized how much I love the tomatillo sauce until I realize I only had one little cup to work with. Just maybe, maybe if they have the salsa bar out, this place will jump to a 5.

Mr Cancun, your move sir.
author: Dorian T.

description:
I cannot believe this Taqueria has 4 stars! 

Pros:
Nice and fast service
Convenient location

Cons:

The food 
The sauce is bland
The tortas are not good
The burritos are not good
author: Lisa M.

description: I was a bit skeptical because I'm very strangely picky about my tacos. I like them plain and unhindered by extras (seriously). I ordered the Carne Asada and Carnitas and they were both delicious. Simple ingredients with meat that tasted delicious, I wonder to myself why it took me so long to try this place out.
author: Shauna S.

description: This place is like El Farolito but you do not have to go all the way to the Mission. Great Mexican food that is greasy, deep fried, refried that just hits the spot. All the meats are fantastic from al pastor to carne asada. Prices are fantastic. Neighborhood is sketch and the restaurant is not the most comfortable place but I would take great food over that any day.
author: Ed L.

description:
$6 Super Burrito, 12 feet wide, delicious. Value Mexican.

Taqueria Cancun is delicious, small , and super cheap. Task a member of your party to grab the first table available while you wait to order. The green salsa is where it's at, the the tortilla chips have enough salt to raise the blood pressure measurably, but the burritos are delicious and come with the chips. If you only have $6 for lunch, come here and fill up.

The downside of this place is that you can see the dish area, and let me tell you, that's not a feature unless you like to know how the dishes are (not) washed and sanitized. Cutting boards from meat getting hosed off instead of properly washed and sanitized is not something that should be happening, much less being seen. Maybe the department of health will fix this, but more likely those with a keen eye will want to face the windows ;)
author: Matthew R.

description:
I think TC in the Mission rocks, but I went to the Market St location several times during my first weeks here in SF, and figured it's got to be the same, right?  

Well, the food was pretty good, if erratically inconsistent, but it all ended for me when a roach climbed out of my chips-n-salsa tray and onto the table, then into my motorcycle helmet.  I took it outside and shook it out, uncertain of what it was.  When I got home, a quick google search of "cockroach" confirmed my fears, reddish brown color and all.  Yuck.

I wish I was making this up, but I'm not.  If there's a way to report this kind of thing, I'd like to know how (edit - someone told me how, thanks!)

I'd give 0 stars but I don't think you can.

I've since had other burritos, and have gradually worked my way back to the Mission location, but I am never eating at the Market St TC ever again.
author: dan s.

description:
This place is great to go to if you're looking to see what a true San Francisco taqueria is all about. The salsa is fresh, and the food comes out pretty tasty.

I like that you can get Coca Cola in a bottle here.  Its more sugary ... mmmm ... bzzzz

The cleanliness could be rightfully questioned, but there is a Virgin of Guadalupe on the back wall, so everything will be OK.
author: Wes T.

description:
I would never have sought this place if not for convenience.  After happy hour at Showdown, we decided to stumble over here to get some food in our bellies.  I can't describe my happiness upon seeing EGGS on the menu.  Wooo eggs!  At 9pm!  

B and I split a plate of the eggs con chorizo, which came with beans, rice, salsa, and sour cream.  It was delicious.  More chorizo than eggs, interestingly enough.  I'm sure that dish was about 10% grease, because I did NOT feel good for a long time after devouring it.  The eating experience is worth it though.

We also each got a lengua taco, which was delicious.  The chunks of meat are a little larger than I am accustomed to, but still tender and flavorful.  

It is important to note that THERE ARE NO RESTROOMS.
author: Lydia W.

description:
I've been there once with my friend, her boyfriend and my boyfriend. I gotta tell you this place is the best ever. Even though we went really late at night the food was still very good! Plus the price was surprisingly very good!!!

I made my boyfriend go back yesterday to get me a vegetarian burrito... OMG!!!! AMAZING!!!!!! I ate it in 15 minutes and still wanted more! 

I think I found my new haven.. and I'm making it the spot to go for really good food!
author: Lena S.

description:
2.5 stars. 

Benefit of the doubt since I tried the wet burrito not the super.

Place is your typical hole in the wall Mexican joint. Fairly good prices. Carne asada was not very memorable, some of the pieces were burnt to a charcoal-like state.
author: Mike I.

description:
Best review picture ever, so appropriate! 

Fast service and reasonable prices, this is a great place to go for lunch if you're on a budget or time crunch.  Very heavy, greasy food so it will fill you up and stain your clothes at the same time.  A TL staple, and if you're looking to fill up this is a great place to do it. However, El Castillio's down the street is better if you have a couple extra minutes.

Specialties: Veggie Burrito (Mojado), Tortas, and Super Casadilla are all BANGIN'!
author: Gabriel C.

description:
I agree with a number of people here.  Not the best burrito in the city, but their veggie variety might be the best of its kind.  It all coems down to the ingredient, especially the half avocdao that is put in each burrito.  

Also, price is definitely reasonable at approx $5.  

It is great for take out and they have a few tables as well.  Also, tenderloin location makes convention center lunches doable....
author: Andrew S.

description:
Oh dear sweet Jesus, this sucker was HUGE. Seriously. I'm typically a member of the clean plate club (whereas Kevin L is reigning President) but I felt like a barely put a dent in this monster.

So here's what you do.

1. Find a friend. A hungry one.
2. Drag their ass to Taqueria Cancun a few minutes after 9am (they say they open at 9, but that's apparently up for debate).
3. Order ONE (just one, trust) Super Breakfast Burrito. Yes, you want the Super.
4. While you wait, pop open a bottle of Mexican Coke.
5. Enjoy that perfectly sweet non-chemically flavor. 
6. Pick up your burrito from the friendly man behind the counter. Be totally grossed out by the weight of the foil baby and the fact you're going to put that in your stomach.
7. Peel back foil, take a bite, pass to friend, repeat. 
8. Skip out of Taqueria Cancun with happy tastebuds, so thankful you read my review and didn't try to eat the entire thing by yourself. Because we all know that leads to insane food coma and full day loss of productivity. 

My favorite things about this burrito? First, the mix of ingredients, and the fact that they themselves were mixed. No Chipotle-famous rice pocket here! I also loooved the fresh guacamole and the not-too-spicy-but-oh-so-tasty-on-its-own chorizo. Delicious. And yes, of course the size. I also sampled Hubert's while in town and while it was almost as delicious, I wasn't as nearly impressed. Sorry, but size matters.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
About five minutes before 0900, our troupe of hungry CMs walked in the door in this delightfully garishly interior decorated hole-in-the-wall in search of a delightful breakfast burrito.  Disappointingly, we were promptly told that they didn't open until 0900 (in about ten minutes, according to the guy behind the counter), even though it was clearly 0858.  Meh.

Given the option to wait or to find sustenance elsewhere, we figured we'd hang around for a little bit since none of us were in a hurry and Monday was a late start anyway.  They were nice enough to offer us some free chips and salsa while we sat around waiting for the grill to heat up.  Not that the salsa or guac was particularly awesome, but it was a really nice gesture and took the edge off my ravenous hunger.

It wasn't until nearly 0910 that they actually took our order, but set right to work on making us three enormous breakfast burritos (or the "super" variety) with all the fixin's.  And I mean -all- the fixin's: shredded cheese, chorizo, rice, beans, salsa, avocado, and more!  These massive monstrosities that ended up landing on our plates weighed as much as newborn babies.  Mmm.  Get in mah belly!

Although I powered through mine, barely slowing down, Petey managed to finish about 95% of his.  Kathleen, even with help, made it through half of hers before tossing in the towel.

If I had to label these tortilla bombs with a single word, it'd undoubtedly be "epic."
author: Kevin L.

description:
The location couldn't be much worse or sketchy, nestled right in the middle of the mid-market hell-hole the City can't seem to clean up, but the food could not be much better either.  The Mission location of this taqueria has long been a favorite, but I had never tried the Market Street location until today.  Despite 2 near fights right outside the place, and despite my need to sit by the door to make sure no one stole my bike (though it was securely locked outside), I couldn't have enjoyed my burrito more.  
Many a yelper has lamented the lack of excellent taqueria fare in the Fidi/Soma/Union Square area, and I completely agree. Too often a burrito seeker is stuck with boring meats, steamed and limp tortillas, tasteless salsas and other Mex-Faux-Pas.  Not at Cancun.  
My burrito's tortilla was grilled and flaky, but still held together throughout the whole meal.  The cheese was melted and tasty, the meat was most excellent...this confirmed Mexican Food Fanatic was a happy boy.  
So long as you can bear the Mid-Market/Loin/Skid Row scene out front (and sometimes inside), your taste buds will thank you.
author: Blake W.

description:
This is probably my favorite burrito place in all of SF...or even all of California. They put fresh avocado on their super burritos...and their pico de gallo is so good. I always get a super pork burrito al pastor.

It's not in the best neighborhood, and doesn't have the best dining atmosphere, but get your burrito to go and you are golden.
author: Emily W.

description:
Another day, another torpedo-sized burrito.

Today's attempt at steamrolling through a San Francisco burrito was the weakest yet - I could nary make it halfway before throwing in the towel. The Pillsbury log was expertly stuffed and wrapped with the omission of onions and salsa, and it actually contained a tolerable amount of cilantro despite my fear of the contrary. 

I also dabbled in a tasty beverage called "horchata", which was ladled up from a terrifyingly large vat of white liquid. It was described to me as a type of rice milk smoothie, seasoned with cinnamon. It was really tasty but had a bit of a tooth-slicking quality to it, if that makes any sense. Like, it left my mouth really cottony. Wish we had some semblance of this beverage back in Canada...
author: Kat F.

description: I'm from the LA, so I'm a taco and burrito snob.  I'm the type to go on taco runs to multiple trucks in LA on random nights.  I had the al pastor super burrito.  Enjoyed it but I feel something was missing.
author: Steven U.

description:
Not even the urban decay of Sixth Street can stop the full Mex-can throttle of Taqueria Cancun! If you're a fan of this Mission institution, this branch on Market and 6th will not leave you disappointed.

Sure the location is a bit sketch, but let me tell: those magical carne and pollo asado tacos do not lose any flavor or substance here. Why I had three for lunch just yesterday, washed down with a Mexican Coke, and am considering going back again today.

Believe you me, there is no better Mexican food in the surrounding five blocks, and probably then some. If you work in SOMA or Union Square... heck even the Fi-Di, this should be required eating. Every other neighboring "taqueria" -- and I use that word loosely -- is just a let down.
author: Nish N.

description: Crappy chips, cheap food.
author: Michael E.

description: Came with my classmates for lunch the other day . I had the Carne Asada super burrito which tasted decent . They either didn't put sour cream or didn't put enough because I could not taste it in the burrito . I was kinda disappointed about that because I love my burritos with sour cream . The burrito came with chips , salsa , and guacamole which was nice . I loved their guacamole ... it was full of flavor . Loved how it was nice & spicy !
author: Eileen L.

description:
I went here at the suggestion of a coworker.

I've reviewed some holes-in-the-wall before, but this place is the most "holey" of them all. Very small place. Total dive. In a not-so-nice area of Market St, surrounded by shuttered businesses. The dude taking orders looks like a younger and slimmer Brian Cox (think Manhunter). Not much seating at all. Clientele who are um...well, very streetwise, so to speak. If you're going here at night, it's best to know how to handle yourself. If it's past sundown and seedy characters spook you, find another place to eat.

Anywho, I had the burrito mojado. As usual, I told them to spice it up, i.e., basically set the damned thing on fire without the flames. And they did so.

Quantity: Excellent. Lunch and dinner combined. They even give you (fresh) chips with two kinds of salsa.

Flavor: Very good. Chicken was fresh, broiled, and the combo of tomato, onion, and spice brought out the flavor very nicely.

Speed of service: very quick. And they were busy (mostly with takeouts and phone orders).

Value: you'd be hard-pressed to get this much food, at this quality, for this price, in San Francisco. It's true. Ya would.

But get the order to-go if the down-and-out bother you.

I'm definitely going to be hitting this place up again in the future.
author: Tim B.

description: Excellent burritos. The area is sketchy as hell, and the place is tiny, but they do have good food here, for reasonable prices. It's definitely worth a stop in if you're unfortunate enough to be in the area.
author: Jim P.

description:
Pros:
They put REAL avocado in their super burritos!
The meat is sometimes cooked fresh.

Cons:
They put WAYYYY too much onion in their burritos.
The meat is sometimes not cooked fresh.
author: Felicity M.

description:
I didn't realize I'd already reviewed this Cancun location.  I've been back several times in the last few months, I haven't noticed the rice being buttery as I mentioned in my initial review; I must have been imagining things.

Lately I haven't been eating nearly as much meat as in times past, and I've grown damn fond of the Cancun veggie burrito.  It deserves much praise.

The location still sucks, and yeah the chips are awful, but the salsas are very good, and if you ask for it they'll give you a bottle of the ever-important Tapatio.  This is a legit taqueria open late that doesn't require you to go to the Mission.  Just be ready to deal with the crackheads.
author: Joseph N.

description: My heart sinks at the thought of having to say 'adios' to what has been my favorite Taqueria in SF since 1999. What brought me back time and again was the mix of flavors, the heat of their salsa verde, and their slightly smaller-than-their- competitors' veggie burritos with price to match. But alas, Cancun has bumped their smaller-than-their- competitors' veggie burritos price up to $7.60 (with tax), a near $1 increase from one month ago, comparable with the higher prices of their competitors. Combined with the stale chips and the lack of a salsa bar, I regret to say other SF taquerias are a better deal. So sad. And, honestly, I'll be back to Cancun but only for the purposes of nostalgia.
author: Brian K.

description:
So... After hearing great things about this place from my coworkers, I grabbed a burrito there for lunch today.  Got a huge veggie burrito + chips and salsa for $5 and some odd cents.  Little did I know, I also got a little something extra.

I got back to the office and was enjoying my veggie burrito - actually - when I grabbed a chip from the bag and guess what came with it?!?!?! A COCKROACH.  Yep, a cockroach.

I almost couldn't believe it.   It slithered out from under the pile of chips just in time to ruin my lunch.  Better I found it at the beginning, I suppose...

Needless to say, I will not be going back. And I can't finish my burrito.  Headed out for lunch Round 2.
author: Amy S.

description:
I got a carne asada wet burrito. It was made quickly and it was big and somewhat affordable. Approximately $7.50

Taste-wise it was ok. Not as zesty as I hoped and it tasted a little clean/bland.

It's not bad, but it only made me miss Los Angeles mexican food even more.
author: kevin l.

description:
I am going to have this biggest food baby ever after this place.

My five bucks gets me at LEAST 2 1/2 meals here considering the portions are ginormous! I've passed this place hundreds of times but never stopped in. 

Last night on our way of bad decision making and reckless shinanigans my friends wanted to stop by for their "super nachos"... HEAVEN in a white foam to-go box. Honestly there were 5 of us and we were all equally filled.

For the location the place is fairly clean with your usual characters. 

I can't wait to go back for my burrito fix.
And of course my beloved mandarin jarritos!
author: Amanda S.

description:
small hole in the wall... yes 

more meat then you 'll see at a thunder from down under show... yes 

We stumbled (literally) upon this place after a long night of long islands and dancing... the sweet fragrance of lengua tacos filled our nostrils and dragged us from the corner of market and 6th. 

My natural carnivorous instinct kicked in and I was compelled to order 2, 3, 5 tacos!!! But our Uncle said "No! these tacos will literally punch you in the face and leave you on your ass" 

Hmmmmmm... one should not eat food that will leave one on their ass... I thought. 

I will play it safe... 2 tacos. 

Stick to a meat I am familiar with... Carne Asada. 

After a short wait... heaven was then laid before me... a perfectly put together taco all wrapped up like a chubby baby in cute checkered blanket. 

The taco was amazing! 

Tiny tip: If your a wimp like me... 1 taco is plenty.
author: Stephanie R.

description: I found this place because I was unable to get to El Farolito and back to my office in adequate time. It was a serviceable alternative. Nothing in my experience would bring me back here. I stopped in once because my friend wouldn't drive to El Farolito. I think they should just sell their business to El Farolito
author: Irwin M. F.

description: You'll love the food but fear for your life!! Or at least order to-go.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Went here for lunch, it was pretty good.  Worth the long walk? Probably.  Worth braving the shady part of Market St.?  Why not.

I had a regular chicken burrito and while it's not the best burrito I've had in San Francisco, it's certainly one of the better ones.
author: Ben B.

description:
Previously I had stated that I hated this location. I take that back. The dudes are cool, and I like the burrito flavor. It's def no Mission Street, but it's closer to my life OKAY. They don't always have horchata, huh?? Also, expect to rub elbows with some creeps cuz this place is tiny.

Salsas so good.
author: Brittany L.

description: A little part of the Mission on the corner of 6th and Market.  This is the last standing business that has survived the gentrification of 6th and 7th street.  Quality is  a step down from the 19th/ Mission and 26th/ Mission locations, but, still solid.
author: Sam T.

description: They claim to have the best veggie burrito in the city. That's probably true if you like meat, because the tortilla is heated on the same grill as the meat, even fir the vegetarian burritos. Other than that, I'd say this is an good place to get a burrito. Nothing special, but it will get you fed for a very good price.
author: Lukáš L.

description:
This place is perfection! After walking around for so long, we stumbled upon this place and we were definitely skeptical. When you walk in, it's like a long hallway and so tiny but the food is amazing here!

Their tortillas are freshly made on premises which makes it SO good, they are slightly flakey and so GOOD. The burritos are definitely huge too. Definitely good for the price!
author: Michelle H.

description: The taqueria cancun burrito has a special place in my heart. I definitely feel like I can't move for about 20 minutes if I finish one but hey, I was loving every minute of that rito in my mouth.. mmmmmmm
author: Rohan S.

description: Awesome taqueria, everything you'd expect from an authentic Mexican joint.  The food is delicious and budget-friendly, they use real avocado instead of the diluted green guac other inferior places do and the portions would please anybody w/ an above average appetite.  Highly recommend sticking w/ the burritos here, it's something they excel in. Other items such as the combo plates, quesadillas, tacos aren't as great.  As w/ most taquerias, the seating is extremely cramped so it's probably better to eat elsewhere.  It's the TL, so don't walk around w/ bling or wads of scrilla.  Some focker actually tried to pick pocket me right outside once.  This ain't the 'burbs so safety is an issue at night..once the crack heads get up from their sleeping hrs.  Just be cool, don't look all paranoid and vulnerable.  Better yet, walking around w/ a mean mug would help.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Their veggie burrito is great--tons of avocado and sour cream. Their nachos are also great. Their super tacos are huge. Their agua frescas aren't very good though.

& WARNING: THEIR FREE CHIPS AND SALSA SUUUUCK!
author: Shauna T.

description: Carnitas and al pastor tacos were excellent!
author: Colleen M.

description:
LOVE IT. I didn't notice anything overly grimy but then again I live in SOMA so I'm used to it. 

The wet veggie burrito, is GIANT, cheap and absolutely delicious. The salsas are very very good. 

Tasty, really cheap and open late. I wish they served beer or even better.....margaritas.
author: Hilarie S.

description: Good food, for a good price.  A place ill hit up a few more times
author: Charles F.

description:
I'm too traumatized to go back to this place.  The last time I went they stuffed gobs of cilantro (heretofore to be referred to as the evil weed) in my burrito.  To their credit, they did make me a new one sans the weed, for which I was grateful.  

 What really left a lasting impression was when we walked out, there was a recently expired homeless man laying under a tarp in front of the restaurant.  I don't think the restaurant had anything to do with his demise.

Luckily, that is the only Cancun restaurant where I've experienced this phenomenon.
author: Landy G.

description:
Pretty dang good. I didn't get salsa on my regular carne asada burrito but that's my own fault. I added the salsa they gave me for chips myself after discovering the dryness and it was great! I usually don't dig pico de gallo type salsas (not a fan of tomatoes) but it was good. 
I'm usually a veggie burrito type but I decided for something different. 

Definitely the least desirable part of downtown but whatever. Some guy was going balstic on PCP or something outside. It was quite... entertaining? An experience? Irrelevant to the burrito? 
D. all of the above
author: Shelby H.

description:
As others have said, this is a tiny hole in the wall place in a less-great part of Market. It can get pretty packed and hot in there with an "entertaining" crowd.

It's excellent "after bar/club" food because it's cheap, filling and tasty. The super quesadilla is particularly impressive.

Like most greasy post-drinking places, I'm less sold on it sober. The so-so produce is much more obvious. However, it's still cheap and filling.
author: Darrien A.

description: I ordered a super steak burrito, they gave it to me like 2 minutes after, worst burrito ever I had to force myself to eat half since it cost me 7.05 but I just couldn't eat it the meat was old the cheese tasted old everything about the burrito was nasty the place is dirty..save your money and go somewhere else this place sucks I'm Mexican and I can tell you you're getting ripped off going here ill probably get sick expired burrito :0 gross
author: Oliver N.

description:
Despite the shady neighborhood and seating for only about 16, this place is usually pack with all sorts of characters.  Definitely an interesting crowd of people, more than anywhere in the Mission that I've experienced.  I'm in this neighborhood often (don't ask why) and there is always someone trying to sell goods to the workers, anything from shoes, cds, to watches. 

My last burrito from this past Monday lacked flavor and meat..  I was somewhat disappointed, but will go back because it's one of the cheapest places to grab a quick bite.  For some odd reason, I really like their salsa.  I think it's a little different from their main shop on Mission Street.  It contains a dash of Lime juice that liven up things a little and adds a little pazazz!!!

THIS is the YUCKY part;
I don't know if anyone ever noticed, but what's with the chips?  The chips comes in a foil wrapped basket. 
A.  This only means that they don't wash the foil
B.  I know they don't change the foil 
C.  Well, you know someone slobbered all over their chips.  However, I don't think they would reuse the chips, but for sure the foil is not changed each time, daily, or weekly - possibly bi weekly, perhaps.  

You heard that the dirtiest place in a bar is the pretzel bowl right? Well this is the same thing, but 23 times worst!!!  Some of the customers here lack hygiene.  I'm sure that they haven't showered for weeks, let alone washed their hands recently.

The secret is to get it to go.  You at least get it in a small plastic bag, avoiding the germ infested chip foiled basket.

stinky tofu
author: StinkyTofu S.

description:
When I left for college, people said I would change.

When I left the US to live abroad, the same thing.

When I left for law school, I was still the person I was years ago--impatient, nitpicky, hated Mexican food with a habanero fire. 

But something happened yesterday. I had Mexican food and I really liked it. I, who never looked at salsa and gaucamole without slightly cringing, savored every morsel of my $3 Super Taco with chorizo. It was irresistible--especially with the fresh, firm avocado.

This was a five-star taco that I had to knock down two stars for because the cook forgot my order and the place wasn't very sanitary--what can I say, I'm still impatient and nitpicky. But I don't hate Mexican food anymore. In fact, I'm sure it's top 50 in my list of favorite cuisines now.

I'll be back here soon for another life-changing experience.
author: Liz T.

description:
Great, cheap, Mexican food, but really bad tortilla chips.  

Can someone tell me why so many Mexican places in San Fran have the worst chips ever? It's so weird, it's like all these places collaborated to have really terrible tortilla chips, but awesome food. I don't get it.
author: Anthony M.

description:
I've ordered the Super Burrito several times from this place, and it's been fantastic each time.  The burrito's hefty and tastes great.  They use real chunks of avocado!  Mmm...  avocado...

Excellent price!  Costs significantly less than other Mexican restuarants in the downtown area--and I've tried several--yet the food is much better made and tastes waaay better.

The Bad, though:  the location.  I personally don't mind walking there to get a nice, juicy burrito, but I know some people might be a bit bothered by the large number of homeless in the area.

P.S. Cash only
author: Thuan N.

description:
I've eaten here quite a few times and have never died, so that's good. Actually, this is a good place if you have a craving for authentic Mexican food for lunch near 6th and Market. The seating is cramped but the service is good, and they stock you with plenty of tortillas, which is a MUST for me. 

Your other option for Mexican food in this area is Andale or Rubios in the Westfield Food Court. Taqueria Cancun is better than Rubios and cheaper than Andale.
author: Lupe P.

description:
I went here in the hour break between Lovefest daytime and Lovefest afterparty with a group of guys I'd known in high school. One lives near Civic center and promised that  I would not get food poisoning from this place despite the questionable hygiene of the establishment. It's so small, the dish washing area is in the same part of the restaurant as where customers are supposed to be eating. I was a bit disgusted upon entering, to tell the true.

But I ordered from there anyway. I got a regular grilled chicken burrito and it was massive ($4.99). I could only finish half of it and I was stuffed afterward. It had a great spice and just the right amount of every ingredient.

Additionally, the staff was very fast and helpful for the length of the line at the time we went inside. We got our food fresh and hot in less than 20 minutes with only 2 people working behind the counter and probably 20 people in line ahead of us. 

So the food was a solid 4 stars. I'd go back again were I not totally freaked out by the crack addicts in the street outside and the potwash sink in the customer area (how they passed heath inspection with a code violation like that.. i have no idea)
author: Stephanie H.

description: Burritos don't compare to the better taquerias in the mission, which have much more flavorful meat and salsa.
author: Neil R.

description:
Anyone who's judging the socioeconomic plights of those in the doorway isn't paying enough attention to the deliciousness that requires two hands to hold, and an entire face to behold. 

Seriously, let's all get past our burrito pretenses.  The vegetarian burrito is a delight.  The al pastor is blessed.  Warning, the salsas are a bit more picante than they look.  That is NOT guac.  And green does not spell an evolutionary safe to eat, not in this case.  Significant spiciness.  I know this invites barbs from those who practice with Guatemalan insanity peppers... Save it.  The green sauce is hotter than its friendly hues imply.  The chips have a weird texture, and I'm back-and-forth on whether that's a good weird.  

The food is ready before you're done pouring yourself a delicious glass of tap h2o.  Cept you should be having on of their  fresh fruit juices, which are above average (but not a must-get).

There are more consistently great places in the Mission, sure, but whilst out-of-town guests wax consumerist down the street at the H&M, you can sneak to this one to grab some consumerism mas delicioso.  Also convenient before one of those megashows at the Warfield.  Or at the strip club next door?  Sorely lacking in a seafood option.  

Always tough to choose between this and Tu Lan.  And that new chicken place 'twixt isn't gonna make this slummy corner any less delicious (look I avoided that awkward rhyme with yummy heh)

PS I have a little leftover nub of an al pastor super in my fridge.  And it makes me salivate and feel like the luckiest boy in the world.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Very good tacos, finely chopped meat (& chicken), cilantro, the works... $2.25 per. Haven't tried the burrito (yet).(Tacos featured the small, round tortillas.)  I agree with many of the positivo comments here.

The nagativos?

- limited seating (7 tables)
- no bathroom
author: M Z.

description:
BEST taqueria near the downtown area period!
Super cheap and delicious tacos and burritos!
The area around it might not be the best, but it's much safer than in the past.
author: George M.

description:
Dude, this is the best (Carne Asada)burrito mojado I have ever had in my life.
No bull and you can't go to Mexico and order one because It's not Mexican.

Every time I'm in San Francisco I make sure to hit it up...

Mind you you'll burn your face off if not careful.
I order the salsa on the side and 2 beers.
author: jose h.

description: If you order a burritio without extra meat you are going to be pissed. If you order extra meat you are going to be less pissed. This place used to be the place that burrito dreams were made, now it is....not so much. Alambre is great though, this location just sucks for burritos.
author: S.E. G.

description:
Just came here on a recent vacation to San Francisco and I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!  The burrito is close to the best burrito I have ever had and I didn't need to go down to Mission.  Yipee!! 

I had the carnitas burrito and the meat was so juicy.  It was really really delicious.  I think my burrito was about $6 and it was huge!  My friend and I shared it and we were both full for hours.  It also came with free chips and salsa.  

I will definitely come back if I'm ever in the area.  I have to warn you that it is a hole in the wall.  It's probably not very clean and I saw a piece of paper saying that they 're no longer in violation of some food code.  I guess that's a good sign...but it does make you wonder.  I still say it's worth it if you don't have a weak stomach!!
author: k k.

description:
Great Mexican food without the SOMA prices. You can roll into Taqueria Cancun for lunch and pick up a super burrito for $5.50. It's a small place but the staff are friendly and fast. You'll have a piping burrito in no time.

I tried the chicken super taco per some other Yelp reviews. They were great but oh so messy. I might have to go the burrito route next time. Give this place a try for lunch if you're nearby, you won't regret it.
author: Aaron V.

description:
If I could I'd give it 3.75 

T.C. on Market isn't as cool as the one in the mission, you know it, I know it, we all know it. It does have a goddamn tasty veggie burrito, for 4 bucks though, and when you're coming home from class late, nothing hits the spot quite like it. In the tenderloin area, I would wager, its the best bank for your buck, burrito wise. If I'm wrong, please correct me, because I love burritos and I don't want to go all the way to the mission to get mine.
author: Dan M.

description: Shit location. AMAZING steak/shrimp burrito.
author: Nate M.

description: For the price, quality, and quantity Taqueria Cancun is the best place in SF in my opinion. Love the green sauce!!!
author: Minh V.

description:
It always looks like someone is shooting a zombie movie out front, but who gives a shit, cause these guys make a bangin burrito for a few bucks and they grill their tortillas !

I don't give a crap how much coriander your Zagat rated Taqueria jams in their texMex roll - you lose - these guys win.
author: David L.

description:
i'm basically drugged into giving any T.C. a high mark because they have that green sauce that is like crack to me.

so i'm probably missing the point other people make about how the burritos aren't actually that good, or whatever.

(the other thing that kills me in a good way at T.C.s is the cevehe, but i dunno that this locale has it? i get it at the bernal heights one.)
author: Raoul D.

description: This Taqueria is extremely small. It also does not have Carnitas(fried-pork). Which Taqueria doesn't have Carnitas? That doesn't make it a taqueria. The Burritoes isn't bad with any meat. But carnitas is great in any mexican cuisine. Sounds like I like "pork"
author: Matt G.

description: Super tasty food and a whole lot of it for a good price!! Love it here, the "mojado burrito" makes an awesome dinner...and breakfast and/or lunch the next day :)
author: Kat R.

description: Of the three locations I know of, this has to be the grimiest of the bunch, but closest to me. I suggest the one around mission and 27th, clean and don't have to worry about bums hassling you for change and trying to touch you while you eat. Seriously order to go, the staff don't even bother to stop crackheads from panhandling and ruining their customer's appetites. The price is right and it is quite tasty.
author: Onika C.

description:
A colleague and I go here for lunch on a weekly basis. Given the size of their signature "Wetback Burrito", it's a good thing we have a 6 block walk back to the office! The free chips and salsa with every order are an appreciated touch, though I wish they still had the water dispenser out on the counter. (You now have to ask for a glass of water. Still free, but also still only 6oz.) The food is always tasty whether you get burrito, enchilada, nachos, or quesadilla. In addition to the normal meat options, you can also get beef tongue and beef head, if you want. A small taste is available before you order an entire burrito-full, which is nice.

The staff are friendly; the cooking area is visible and looks clean; and the decor is bright and festive. Once in a while the 8 tables are full, but turnover is high. Caution: No bathroom, and some sketchy folks from the neighborhood sometimes wander in or past. Also, while it's level enough for handicap access, there really isn't space to get a wheelchair in, and even people with walkers or canes would likely feel cramped.

Trivia: They've won the SF Guardian's "Best of the Bay" award for Best Taqueria for 9 of the past 10 years.
author: Bill B.

description: Best breakfast I've had at a restaurant in a while. The chorizo and eggs is awesome. The Chorizo isn't too greasy and very well seasoned. The salsas are good and the tortillas were above average.
author: Derek S.

description:
So this weekend I saw Legally Blond the Musical (very c-u-t-e) with the girlfriends... it was playing at the Golden Gate Theater, which is basically at 6/Market (yuck). 

Since I was by myself because I was dropped off early (like over 1 hour early.... miscommunication on what time the show actually started, oops!) I decided to wander across the street to Taqueria Cancun and grab a couple tacos.

I ordered my tacos and was happily munching away when this super skinny homeless lady with spiky hair wanders in and starts yelling, "them beef tongue tacos, them beef tongue tacos, are those like COW BEEF TONGUE TACOS? Gimme one!" 

Except she didn't have any teeth so it sounded like, "beeeth tung tacoooth, beeeth tung tacoooth..." and then she got spittle on MY taco as she walked to the counter. 

And I almost hurled. 

What a waste of a perfectly good taco. 

So in the end the food was fine, actually quite good!

But the location and the place itself was just too dingy for me.... no more for this little lass.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
The grilled chicken tacos with avocado ("sin crema por favor") are amazing here. Two of those and a trip down to Godiva in the mall for dessert, and you're in $8 meal heaven. Don't forget coca cola in the bottle to really feel like you are in Tijuana living the good life.

Thus, I give it 5 stars, but it is in a "shady" neighborhood as others have described. I've had multiple electronic items, such as a VCR, offered for sale to me there, but in its defense, I left my laptop bag there once and when I came back half an hour later to get it, I was pleased to find that the outstanding and friendly staff had saved it behind the counter for me and were worried I'd forget it, and it had not turned into the latest hot street sale item on Market and 6th.
author: Mike G.

description: I went here with high expectations based on the other Yelp reviews but I was a little disappointed.  The food was okay, nothing spectacular.  The service was really what did it as I had to wait almost fifteen minutes for two items, even after multiple people came in after my order was placed and got their plates served before me.  Probably won't be going back.
author: Robert S.

description:
I really need to come here more often.  

One evening, my friend and I stopped off here to grab a burrito before hitting a movie at the Embarcadero theater.  While standing in front of the glass counter waiting to order, I found myself spacing out, staring at the plastic basket of salt and pepper packets, which happen to be at eye level.  Staring back at me on the rim of the basket was a creature with long antennae waving hello.  

"Is that a cockroach?"

My friend just grinned at me. "Unh huh". 
 
We both shrugged, ordered our burritos, and enjoyed them immensely as we walked down Market Street as the moon rose over the ferry buliding.

The End.
author: Marlys B.

description:
They've won consistent, consecutive awards in the past for being an SF delight. yesterday, I got a boiled (or is it broiled? wtf is the difference.. omgosh i dunno!) chicken burrito which came with salsa, sour cream, avocado, rice and beans. Including tax, 5.97 peered at me enchantingly from the cahiser's register.

If you're veering for an alternative to Westfield's horrendous eateries, this place is worth the extra couple blocks.
author: Carl Z.

description: Ok, I love Taqueria Cancun... it is the best deal for a burrito around. But the 19th and Mission one is SO much better than this Market street location. 5 stars for the burrito mojado (veggie) or taco, great deal, tasty, good food. But -1 for not being friendly, and -1 for not having water available and only grudgingly giving us (two of us) one cup and no easy access to a pitcher for refills. Or more salsa. The 19th Street location does all that and still tastes better :)
author: Amanda S.

description: This place is in a super gross area and has a scarily low health inspection score.  It has the best al pastor super burritos that I've ever had and is super cheap.  The carne asada (the only other thing I've tried) is not very good but who cares?  The al pastor is unreal.  5 stars.
author: M F.

description:
This place rather small, but for the prices and the quality of the food it's pretty good. 

If you are in the area I would say try Tacqueria Cancun out, but it still isn't as good as the Mission, of course. 

Not worth it to make a trek all the way there, but if you live nearby or go to UC-Hastings it's great for a 6 dollar lunch that can fill you up pretty well.
author: Sterling J.

description:
I'm not sure what this place is like during the day, but it is way wicked at night. It's open late, there's always a line out the door and the night would not be complete if there was not a homeless person asking you for some coin. There is a wet burrito that is super amazing. If you don't handle spicy so well, hold the green sauce. It burns like no other. And if you have to pee, plug your nose. It really stinks!

Overall, I'd go here all weekend long at night if I lived in San Francisco.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Absolutely love this place.  The burritos are fantastic, as are the enchiladas and just about everything else I've tried there.  I especially like the fact that instead of some sort of guacamole spooge, they use real avocado slices.

Yeah, the neighborhood is kind of shady, but for any SOMA residents looking for something a little more authentic than Chevy's or cheaper than Maya or Tres Agaves, you've gotta check this place out!
author: Maneesh B.

description: I've been eating here at least weekly for about 5 years. Everything is good except the chips. But the salsa is amazing (especially the verde) so I put up with the chips. The Alhambra platter is awe inspiring but too sloppy to take out. Eating in can be an adventure though. It's cramped and loud and usually busy. The burritos are among the best in the city. The regular chicken is better than the pollo asado.
author: Magic P.

description: I don't know. I've had some pretty good dining experiences at Cancun, but I just wasn't feeling it when I went in yesterday. The restaurant's a little dinky, but generally when I've stopped by Taqueria Cancun, I get my stuff to go. They've got some pretty bomb carne asada super nachos, but I got a carnitas burrito yesterday and it was way more fatty than it probably should have been. I feel like there's only so much I can ask for in terms of being healthy at a burrito joint, but this was kind of gross. Like I said, though. They've got some bomb diggity super nachos to make up for it.
author: Alea G.

description: While tasty and quickly prepared, I was UN-prepared to spend 20 minutes in the bathroom as a result of my burrito intake.  I think I will have to opt for a different burrito option should the urge for a burrito arise.  Also, the place is really small and not for claustrophobic types.
author: Michael G.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written about this place yet--it's such an integral part of my life. 

I've eaten here at least once a week for the past couple of years and I've never had a subpar burrito. No place in the city makes burritos like this. I got crazy once and had the nachos and those ruled too.

I gave this place four stars because you have to periodically stave off bums trying to get your chips, but food and price-wise this place is a solid five.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Very greasy deliciousness. Didn't quite live up to my expectations, although I've heard that the other locations in the Mission aren't better. Even though the Mission is the home of taquerias, it's not very good franchise management if three locations in the same city differ quite a bit. The person I was with got the veggie burrito, which, as so many others have said, is the best veggie burrito in the city. So why can't they find the best meat and make the best overall burrito in the city?

As I'm sure you know, this is not a great location. However, it is convenient if you're going to one of the movie theaters and you want to grab a burrito beforehand. Although if you plan to do this, watch out for serious food coma.
author: Mark A.

description: I try and go here 3 times a week. A super taco is 3.29$ and worth every penny, and probably a lot more. It comes piled high with your choice of meat, salsa, sour cream and fresh avocado. It might not be the cleanest biggest nicest taqueria, but if you like good food it is the place to be.
author: Eric B.

description:
I have eaten at the other T.C.'s in the mission, and I do indeed like the food.  However, my experience at the SOMA location, as might be expected, was much different.  

   I was in a burrito mood and I didn't feel like walking around for a place to eat, so I decided to eat my 'rito in the actual shop, at one of their 6 or 7 small tables.  Ya know when you're eating a hodge-podge of different food items and they just don't mesh well? That's what this burrito was like.  It was dry and each ingredient seemed not to want to socialize with the other.  

   As if that wasn't enough, there was a shameless drug deal taking place right behind me.  I won't say between whom, but I will say that natashka knows what she's talking about.  

  At this point, I am starting to believe there's no decent Mexican food in SOMA.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Burrito sizes down, prices up, rating down.

I wouldn't yelp this place because I forever kept it at 3.5 stars and refused to choose one side or another.  The recent price increase has nudged me down to 3 stars.  A veggie burrito should be $5.00 or less.

I can already see the 80-year-old version of myself,   

"Baaack in my day a burrito was 5 bucks, and they served it with chips, and salsa -- for free!"

Sure gramps.  Whatever.

-------------------

I don't mind paying the extra cash, but the newer, smaller burrito just isn't quite enough to get me through the day.
author: Mat K.

description:
I've been to this place twice and, after today, have no intention of going back. 

The first time i was there, i probably would have given the place a 3.5 or 4. The first thing you notice is that the place is pretty dumpy, but i decided to stay because a friend raved about the food. The super burrito i ordered was cheap and huge, but just OK. They put way too much cilantro in it and i had to spend several minutes picking large chunks out of my burrito.  As everyone else has mentioned- the chips and salsa totally suck.

I decided to venture inside for a burrito again today and, unfortunately, left empty handed. The guy who took my order was rude and dismissive right off the bat. I ordered a super burrito to go, which he apparently wrote down as a super taco, not to go. After noticing that he charged me too little i double checked my order: At which point he proceeded to argue with me about what i wanted for several minute. Finally i said, "You know what, i'm gonna go somewhere else. Give me my money back." And he wouldn't!! He kept arguing with me about it! I actually had to reach over the counter and grab back the $20 i had handed him. It was ridiculous.

It's nice that the food is cheap, but after experiences like this it becomes abundantly clear that you get what you pay for. From now on, i'll shell out the extra 2 bucks for a super burrito at the AMAZING Taqueria Mana on Stockton!
author: A. M.

description: Complete and utter lack of goldfish taco selections. (I had to settle for the breakfast burrito instead.)
author: Ed K.

description:
I totally love this place, the service is fast and friendly and the food is fantastic.  Make sure you get it to go as sometimes the clientele can be sketchy at best, but the food more than makes up for it.

The salsa is pretty good, though the chips are Tostitos or Costco or something.  Make sure you get a Coke in a bottle as well, washes everything down nicely.
author: Darren Z.

description:
Good food = check
Fast service = check
Cheap = check
*Interesting* people inside = check

In general, you can get a decent burrito for lunch. The area is a bit sketchy, but the buritto is decent. $6 burrito with fresh avocado really does it. I highly recommend doing a take out. Eating there is a big no-no
author: Susanto I.

description:
Tacos tacos tacos.  Get the 2 pollo asada tacos.  $5.25, comes with chips and salsa (be careful, usually really hot).  You will not be sorry unless you don't like spicy food.

CASH ONLY.
author: Bobby N.

description: It was borderline forgettable. The portions are decent for the price. I had nachos and my husband got a burrito mojado. I rather make a trip to the Mission and enjoy the Mexican food down there.
author: Annette S.

description: i just finished eating here after reading reviews on yelp. First i was kinda sketch because of the location but i thought what the heck. i ate a carne asada burrito it was  6.50  and wonderful. the beef was really tasty and the cilantro sauce that comes with the chips was awesome. would definitely recommend if your low on cash. me and a friend shared a burrito and still had some left over. aweome place cheap prices
author: Jay A.

description: Great spot for a quick, tasty lunch.  Mexican Coca-Cola, good chips and salsa.  Loved their tacos...mmmm carnitas.
author: Chris G.

description:
I spent a summer eating burritos from Taqueria Cancun when I was at Hastings, so when I was craving a burrito, I thought I'd visit. There's not much of a crowd in the evening due to the crummy 6th & Market location. The place still seems grimey, and you can usually tell what the person who was seating at your table just had.

The pluses are (1) authentic Mission-style burritos, (2) cheap prices, (3) beef tongue and beef head for the adventurous - though I'm sticking to the carne asada, and (4) cheap, tasty, greasy corn quesadilas with white queso oozing from every bite. In fact, I think I love their corn quesadilas more than their burritos.

It's not the best burrito in the City (at least at this location), and you'd probably get better food at Tu Lan a couple doors down, but it's a good option for SOMA/Civic Center Mexican.
author: Timothy O.

description:
They recycle the free chips.  Yup, that's right, if someone doesn't eat all the chips in their bag and leaves them in their tray the busboy dude restocks them up there with the "fresh" chips.  Cool way to recycle, dude.
