This means that if CrackStar Bob, the Will Work For Beer guy with the flesh eating disease at Folsom and Van Ess doesn't eat all his chips maybe I can have them with my order!

Yay!
author: timber y.

description:
By far the weakest (and sketchiest) of the cancun franchise.  But proximity to the Warfield and a lack of other eating options guarantees this place 3 stars.

But seriously, the place is fine.  Not good, bot bad.  Just fine.
author: Steve S.

description: There was a roach in my tortilla chips today.  The manager was entirely nonplussed when I asked for a new basket of chips and didn't even apologize.  Still the best burritos in town for the price.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Carne Asada Torta here was pretty good.
Excellent flavor with very fresh ingredients.

Melon agua fresca was not as good as the Bernal Heights location.
They shred their melon here, chunky. The Bernal Heights variation is much smoother.

The crowd here is very interesting. just around the corner from Tu Lan, the crowd is the same. Anyone can come in, anything can happen. It's fun.

Though there are no steps to hinder access, the narrow space between the counter and tables might be prohibitive.
author: Geordie E.

description: Good place for a cheap burrito, but you must be really hungry to finish it. I couldn't, even after removing all the sour cream that was poured all over my plate. The rice and beans in the filling were still crunchy, definitely not melted and undistinguishable one from another as in other places.
author: Andrea L.

description: Mediocre burritos, bad service and lots of smelly homeless people when I went.
author: M M.

description: Yes, the area is shady, but it is above average Mission Mexican fare and the best late night Tacqueria option hands-down. You get your money's worth and then some here. They don't skimp on the meat and they prepare the orders relatively quickly even when it gets crowded.
author: Nancy F.

description:
My burrito was delicious and one of the better ones I have had in my neck of the woods. Post dinner, I may have given a 5 star review. But then 3am happened and I half woke up because I felt like death: totally nauseous and thinking about how if I didn't get over this I would have to use a sick day for something so lame. This feeling did pass and I was never fully awake for it, so there's still like a 10% chance it was a dream/in my head. Plus it's not like it's the only thing I ate yesterday, but it was one of the last, so I cannot definitively say it was Taqueria Cancun's fault, but if I had to guess...

Yes I went back. What can I say? It was a long day at love fest and I was hungry and working my way towards a hangover or coma-like sleep. I chose the burrito and 8:30 bedtime route. My best friend was in town and we needed a burrito ASAP and this was the closest. It was delicious and my boyfriend and I promtly slept for 13 hours after it. Perfect end to the day.
author: Jennie H.

description:
Best veggie burrito in SF. If you have a fear of body lice, take it to go. 
Oh, and check out the awesome underwater scene painted on the walls (complete with mer-men).
author: Meg I.

description:
The burritos are the way to go, esp. if you make a trip all the way out here for lunch from the FiDi.  3.5 stars for some of the tastiest carne asada for cheap prices.  Chips and salsa were just ok.
If you're in a rush to get back to work, take it to go and enjoy the walk back down market or stroll to Union Sq. for a nice day out.
author: Eric Y.

description:
Eat at any of the other Cancuns and you'll get a 4 star burrito.  This one, I just don't know.  One thing I don't like is the fact that they put Pepsi/Coke in their carnitas when frying it.  A little bit is a tasty bit of spice.  The amount they used on my last burrito's meat was enough for me never to order it again.  It tasted like I was eating a mouthful of burrito and sucking down the pepsi at the same time.  Ick. 
Their salsas are top notch and they give you chips with all orders though.  And the al pastor is pretty tasty.  The carne asada was overcooked dried out last time I had it here.
author: matthew w.

description:
Mexican food doesn't get any better than this! 

I don't know if it's the way the bread is toasted to perfection on every taco and burrito, or if it's the way the cheese has an authentic, thick, sweet, creamy taste to it... This place tops every other Taco Truck, Burrito Shop and hole in the wall I've ever visited in the Bay!

My boyfriend brought me here for the first time after a long night of partying in SF, and I haven't been able to stay away. At first I thought it was just my drunked craving that made it taste so scrumptious, but after trying it again, it tastes even better Sober!

Late night munchies... Cancun Taqueria!... Night when I don't feel like cooking... Cancun Taqueria!... Best of all, I'm always willing to drive from Oakland and throw away $4 toll fee for this small taste of Heaven :)

If you haven't eaten a Cancun Taqueria Super Grilled Chicken Burrito from here, to put it in a nice way... You're Missing out on life!

Don't expect exquisite customer service from the staff. They're nice to say the least. And don't expect a quiet, romantic setting. This place is usually Packed with people, to the point where it's hard to find a table to eat, and people are standing next to you while you eat and they wait in line for their food.
Go in expecting Delicious Food, and a nice sized portions, and you'll leave a Happy Camper :)
author: Sky B.

description:
An affordable taqueria next to sleazy sixth. But don't worry about its location, the neighborhood is safe enough. Just don't drift off of Market Street on this block, and you'll be fine. 

You can make a filling lunch out of most everything on the menu, and everything on the menu will add pounds to your person. The damn chips suck arse, but the burritos definitely are worth their weight  (no pun intended). 

Instructions: March down Market Street, looking up at the restaurant signs, otherwise you'll miss it like we did. Enter, order, ask for extra salsa, then stand there and wait. If your order is to-go, make sure that everything in the bag will survive a walking trip. Be careful, because if the containers list, things get pretty messy.
author: Daniel C.

description:
To explain the five stars, I have to set the scene here: a number of us were doing our DYL thing at Mr. Smith's, and there was some debate going on about whether "liquid dinner" was adequate.   Knowing how these nights tend to go, I had a feeling that liquid dinner wouldn't be sufficient for me, so I started attempting to make a plan to find some food.  After being told that there was nothing decent for several block in any direction at that hour, a couple of us set out to disprove the wisdom of the crowd.  Two sketchy blocks later, we saw Taqueria Cancun.  It was our only hope.

We walked in, and lively Mexican music was blaring.  It was a little intense.  Ordinarily, I would probably not choose to actually stick around here and eat, but sitting in UN plaza at 10PM didn't seem like a good idea, and I'm pretty sure Mr. Smith's won't let you have burritos down on the dance floor, so we suffered through the music.

For the time and place, the burrito was heaven.  Yes, you can probably get a better burrito somewhere at some hour, but with fresh sliced avocados and a healthy portion of carnitas, it was above average.  And did I mention it cost $6?  This place is an oasis for the neighborhood, so five stars it is.
author: Andy G.

description:
I don't like to be eating in there, because people be buggin'. Take your deliciousness (quesadillas are off the al pastor meat rack, yo) to The Luggage Store Gallery next door to eat while enjoying your favorite experimental music every thur @ 8pm. 

Burritos are good, too. Love the carne asada, guey!
author: André C.

description:
Your standard San Francisco burrito with some signature hot sauce.

Given the part of town, the joint itself is quite cramped and pretty dirty. Other than that, the food's great.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Taqueria Cancun is right next to my place on Market.  Yes, it is the ghetto and yes it looks very uninviting but take a whiff of the amazing smells and the temptation to go in is undeniable.  

It is all about the tortas and super tacos (I prefer grilled chicken).  

Other than the weird crack head looking people and the occasional crazy eating leftovers out of the trash can, I would recommend this place to anyone passing through the neighborhood or in need of an inexpensive meal.
author: Rachel R.

description:
For some reason, a lot of people seem to rate this place and/or its sister locations on Mission as "Best of the Bay?"

I have eaten at this Market Street hole-in-the-wall location three or four times now, including once with a friend, who first introduced me to the place.  Each time I was hoping that the experience and the food would be better than the last time and live up to those "Best of the Bay" accolades.  

So anyway, I keep giving this place another chance.  But I've been disappointed every time.  This last time, I wandered in on a cold Monday night around 7 pm.

Strangely, I was  followed by a homeless woman begging for money.  She would not stop hassling me for money, even as I stood waiting to order at the counter.  

Apparently, she thought I was an "angel." Whatever gave her that idea is beyond this mortal coil. She pleaded for money and kept staring into me hoping to connect into me on some level. But I just wasn't going to fall for that again, as I've done in the past several times by giving a dollar or two away to beggars just to get them to go away and leave me be.

So finally, the cashier got impatient waiting for me to order and forced her out -- and even then only after she had harassed two more customers sitting down to eat!

When I did finally order a vegetarian burrito with no sour cream to see if it tasted any good without being drowned with sour cream like I noticed a lot of the other food being served.  

Figuring I had escaped from the "Night of the Living Dead" street theater show known as San Francisco's Market Street, I decided to sit down and eat.  But the cashier instead stuck my food in a bag to go, fully expecting me to leave as if it was my fault the homeless zombie-lady came in after me to beg for money.

In any case, I decided to sit down and eat the burrito while it was still warm.  After opening it up, I found there to be little or no vegetables in the "vegetarian burrito."  The tortilla was dry, toasty off the grill and crunchy, but inside was just a little bit of pinto beans, some cheese , salsa fresco and avocado.  There was also lingering after-taste of seafood from the grill on my burrito -- most likely a fish taco or something else that was on the grill with my tortilla. Also, the free chips were a bit on the burnt side, too.  

Suffice it to say, this was the last time I will be eating at this Market Street location.  Though I was hungry -- and almost anything you eat when you're hungry usually tastes good this time it left me with a strange vibe.  And I usually love almost any burrito I eat, especially when I'm hungry.

I feel it isn't worth the hassles to eat at a place no matter how good others say the food is or how cheap the eats are.  I'd say you might even be better off just going to that franchise burrito place in the San Francisco Center food court.  Either way, you're taking your chances on the food quality and service.
author: Ed M.

description:
I used to live upstairs from this cancun, and let me tell you, i had many experiences with this greasy, artery clogging deliciousness.

Super Burrito with black beans and carne asada will do it for me.
author: Joey R.

description:
I got a carne asada super burrito here a couple nights ago....AMAZING.

The sliced avocado instead of guacamole is such a good touch. Tender, flavorful meat....exceptional burrito. 

Yeah, it's a little sketchy around this location...but that's usually where the best food is found.
author: Aaron A.

description:
Best Vegetarian Burrito
and best marinated steak as found in anything carne asada.
author: SID D.

description: It's on the same block that I live and it is good! Sure I could walk a couple of extra blocks to a taqueria that is slightly better but why go further than you have to. For those who only order burritos I recommend trying their carnitas or pollo asado plates.
author: Manuel R.

description:
I was craving salsa one day while shopping in san fran and asked a valet where to get some mexican food and he said taqueria cancun was close and super cheap, so I checked it out. i got a HUGE black bean, vegan, taco for 1.50 with chips and salsa, and a delicious melon aquas fresca for another 1.50. Satisfied that craving for 3 dollars! 
the location is a little sketch, the decor and atmosphere nothing to rave about, and no bathroom. but for super cheap, fast, decent mexican, i'd go again!
author: Elizabeth J.

description:
Not a good burrito.  The place is shady and disgusting.  My burrito had a soap flavor that was hard to kill even after pouring on 3 cups of their spicy salsa.

Might be good if you are really drunk, but I would suggest going elsewhere.
author: Doug A.

description:
As a Mexican, I vouch for this place... Nouvelle cuisine can kiss my ass.Nuf said. 
Oh and Balazo (which is now closed) sucks and you're an idiot to recommend that over-priced, gringo-ized version of Mexican food. My good friend (gee, another Mexican) digs this place. The stoners who run the Marijuana Club that's in my work building (yes, loads of stories there) thank me all the time for getting them to switch from Balazo. They're all honkies there in case you're keeping score. Oh, one of my best friends is a Wasp, so...
Okay -the mission does rock and you have more choices there but COME ON... Great prices and solid food in an over-priced or otherwise sketchy hood (except Tu Lan)...
author: Raul L.

description:
Got the veggie burrito, big and tasty for less then 5 bux.  Free chips, salsa, and guacamole.  Chips were kind of stale, but whatever.

Minus a star b/c when ah said thank you, the guy behind the counter actively ignored me.
author: Tmon B.

description: Came here earlier today. Service was alright not the coolest but just alright. Food came real fast and it was good, not the best just satisfied my hunger. Me and my girl ate inside and the experience wasn't all that. I personally didn't like how they kept the salsa behind the counter. Or how I gave them all my change in the tip jar all 35 cents of it then I buy a water and have to break a dollar instead of letting me slide 9 cents. I hate change but o well. Overall it wasn't the best spot but I've been to worse. Super chicken burrito was average. MIGHT come back if I'm in the neighborhood might not.
author: Marvin C.

description: Craving some quick, cheap, and delicious hole-in-the-wall Mexican food? Taqueria Cancun has your fix. The prices are great and the portions are large. I got the beef burrito mojado and was full about 1/2 of the way in. The location and atmosphere may not be the best, but the chips, salsa and guac that come with your meal make it worth it!
author: Lisa M.

description: My favorite taqueria in SF!  The one in the Mission has a way better ambiance though.  This place is grimey.
author: AJ B.

description: Cheap friendly, open late and an awesome burrito!
author: Ali B.

description: I know this place has been reviewed many times. Still, I love this place. I've been eating here for years and have never found a better taqueria. I guess El Farolito is a very close second but i'm hardly ever down by 24th anymore. I go here so much the chooks know what i want when i walk in. I like this location better than the one in the mish. I don't know why but it just tastes better. They deserve all the props they get,no doubt. Most taquerias have something off. Meat,beans,something. Cancun nails everything. I'm down for the super quesadilla,no guac. My guac lovin friends swear buy it though. If you are downtown, don't let the panhandlers scare ya, this place is so worth it.
author: Greg H.

description:
Look, they have tasty food here.  Standard taqueria food.  I love the asada plate (corn tortillas, sour cream, beans, rice, etc).  But it's dirty.  I am sitting waiting for my order, and, what was that I saw out of the corner of my eye?  Was it walking piece of carne asada?  No, it's a roach.  Another time, I saw a rat run across the back (coulda been a mouse).  And there is always at least one homeless guy in there stinking the place up.  

Whatever, its at 6th and Market and it tastes good.  I see them grill my food right in front of me, so any bacteria or disease in the roach that accidentally fell into the container of asada is probably pretty sanitized by the time I get it.

Good food.  But not gentrified.
author: Full S.

description: If you're looking for fine dining, this is not your place.  But they have the best veggie burrito in San Francisco.  I haven't tried anything else, because it is sooooo good.
author: Bill K.

description:
I actually lived off of Super Veggie Burritos from this place for like six months.

Dosen't get any better.
author: Miles C.

description: This is part of the regular lunch rotation for my coworkers and I. It's a little bit on the long side of a walk there, but it's always worth it. Cheap, delicious burritos, with complimentary chips and guac. Somewhat obscured from view is the poster for the prawn burrito, which is clearly the most superior of all their burrito varieties. I always leave Cancun with a full, satisfied stomach.
author: Adam D.

description: Very tasty al pastor burritos and super tacos!
author: Sushant P.

description: The carne asada tacos and the carnitas burrito were some of the best I have ever had.
author: Thomas K.

description: Decent, but not blowing me away. I guess I would come here more often  if I ever ate veggie burritos, but that just is not me. I think the biggest negative is they just absolutely stuff their burritos with rice. Way too much. I don't know. What am I missing here? This place always gets voted top burrito in the city but I am just not feeling it like that. There are better places. Oh yeah, avoid this location. Right in the heart of junkieville.
author: Nick H.

description:
i love your burritos i love your burritos i love your burritos.

i'm not even into burritos, man.

but i really love these burritos.

& the music is always blasting, which reminds me of actually being in mexico. plus pictures of saints and a shrine to the holy virgin and that totally perfect use of bright color and paper to decorate, which is what makes me love that mexican style so, so much.

but maybe it's a little too dirty to get five stars, if you know what i mean.
author: Irene S.

description: CERTAINLY my go-to place when i lived in SFO. yea, the burritos are significant in size, but also in taste.
author: Todd A.

description:
yes, mid-market is sketchy as all get out. I once some someone beating the crap out of a wall next door to this location. yes, a wall. But Taqueria Cancun's food is off the chain and with Tu Lan around the corner I would venture to say that 6th and Market may be the culinary epicenter of San Francisco.
I recommend the carne asada super burrito, which if you get no rice really lets the flavors come out, the freshly grilled steak, the whole pieces of avocado. muy muy sabroso!
Other very solid standouts include the tacos, and the quesadilla suiza, which is an incredibly flavorful steak quesadilla. 
Also, don't be scared off by the torta which is basically a super burrito sandwhich replacing the tortilla with a french roll. so so tasty. 
you can tell I'm a fan. 
So, in short, don't worry about the sketchiness of the neighborhood, grab some comida and walk a block back to bloomingdales inf you need to feel like a yuppie again. adios!
author: Gabe b.

description: Chefs doing coke in back explains why burritos are so good.
author: natashka o.

description: I know, Lord, I KNOW  this is not the Mission location... but the fact that we get even a FRACTION of that awesomeness, in this hood... Sheeeit. I'll take what I can get. I could live on one Veg burrito per day, which, for me, can last two meals and is only $5.46 after tax. I actually feel that since seating extends toward the rear of the building, it muffles the noise & the realities outside. You tend to forget that you're on Market @6th. Cancun, take me away...
author: Michelle W.

description:
my favorite mexican joint before i discovered el farolito.

theyre quick, dirty and cheap. they're so quick one time i ordered a carnitas super quesadilla and i got a carnitas super burrito. who cares, i'll take it.

there's hardly enough seating for anyone so plan on taking it to go.
author: Dennis L.

description: Now everyone knows that taquerias can vary in quality by what you order.  One place has awesome carnitas and the other doesnt quite add up,  but has a great lengua.  Take my word for it...get the Prawn Burrito with Black Beans and ask for extra spicy.  This is why I give 5 stars.
author: Mike H.

description: I went here last week because i work nearby and was craving for some enchiladas.  I ordered a chicken enchilada and waited.  Meanwhile, the lady behind me placed her order for a lengua  or "tongue" super burrito.  I watched them make hers and then saw that they put the same kind of meat in someone's enchiladas.  I told the guy that i wanted chicken and he said mine was chicken.  I thought perhaps that the enchiladas i saw them make was for someone else.  I got to work and opened it up and sure enough mine was not chicken.  I will never go back here again!
author: Maria B.

description: No need to go all the way to the Mission for authentic and Delicious Mexican food.  The neighborhood is usually filled with the kind of people that make SF exciting/dangerous/fun/unique too.  I've tried most of the menu...and enjoyed them all.  The quality to price return can't be beat either. Only problem is there is no restroom and I always overeat there.  Viva Taqueria Cancun!
author: James M.

description: The food tastes the same but something about the location and the fact that you're kinda afraid for your life late at night here, makes digesting these tender wrapped bundles of joy a little less pleasant. However, I do think that these are one of my favorite burritos in the city, but I'd venture into the mission and check out the one on 19th & Mission instead of this one... however, if you're strapped for a bite to eat after a show at the warfield then mosey on down!
author: Len S.

description: The Taqueria Cancun at Mission and Valencia es muy bueno.  This Taqueria Cancun, pero, es MUY MALO!  Smaller, Dirtier, and not-fresh-or-tasty-ier than either of the other two Cancuns.  Go instead around the corner for vietnamese from Tu Lan.
author: Ari G.

description: These guys do it right!!! By far the best veggie burrito I have ever had. They use fresh avocado and include chips and salsa... and the burrito is quite filling and satisfying. For some of the best authentic Mexican food for a very fair price... check this place out. When I lived in SF I used to skate the city alot and would most often end up here. Cancun satisfies.  Just don't go wandering down 6th street on accident... it's not in the best area but is worth the adventure :)
author: Joshua L.

description: Can't believe it took me so long to find this inexpensive great hole in the wall taco place.  The super taco on $3 is to die for!  Great people watching!
author: Loren L.

description: Pretty good burritos and this fruity type drink. The seating areas seem kind of dirty, may be they are. Sometimes homeless people would come in and try to talk to the customers but then the workers would kick them out, it is  a little awkward.
author: Janet Z.

description: Not bad at all, it beats eating at the Westfield mall that's for sure.  I will probably go back next time I have a lunch break and want a burrito.  There are better places but this one is definitely good.
author: ben G.

description: Personally, I think this is dirtiest of the three Taqueria Cancuns. The last time I went, there was a crazy guy outside having a discussion with his hammer! Kinda scary. I almost didn't go in, but well, if you've had Cancun's Carne Asada burrito, you know I had to have it, crazy hammer guy or not! So yeah, it's dirty, but I'll be damned if they don't make the best burrito in the city. The "best of" lists are right on this one, my friends. In summary: if you visit this particular Cancun location, be safe and bring a friend...and pick up a Carne Asada Super burrito for me, no salsa. Thanks!
author: Brad L.

description: I ate here today at lunch for the first time. And although it does not reflect Cancun in any way, the burrito I had was pretty darn good. I got the Super Burrito, with grilled chicken and everything else on it. For a little under $8, I got a HUGE burrito and a canned soda. I only ate about 3/4 of the burrito so the other part will be a wonderful late night snack. On the downside, this place is somewhat in the ghetto. When I was in there, I saw no less than 2-3 local bums that made there way into this place. However, if I am judging this location on food alone, it is a place I would recommend and definately make it back to in the near future.
author: Jason B.

description: As an avid carnivore, I readily admit that I know nothing about the Veggie Burrito.  What I DO know is that there's something not quite right about this location...maybe it's the totally flavorless guacamole that they charge an arm, leg & 1st born child for; the tired salsa; the dry meat?!  I know, it's the stale chips that they CHARGE YOU FOR (standard with your food everywhere else, though...wth?!)?!  I dunno, I've had better at way too many other places to waste my money here...what's bad, they had the audacity to raise the damn prices...smh
author: Amoura B.

description: The best Veggie burrito outside of the Mission.  Yes its dirty and gross outside, that's 6th street people, get over it!  I do think the food differs at different Cancun's, somehow the one waaaaay out nearly at Cesar Chavez is super super super yummy..In any case, I stand by my initial assessment.  The very best super veggie at the cheapest price outside of the mish.
author: RJ M.

description: Excellent food for a hole in the wall. Friendly staff and yummy,  spicy, authentic Mexican food. You shouldn't judge this restaurant by its cover.
author: Nicholas F.

description: Enjoyed eating the yummy tacos here, especially the tacos al pastor (marinated pork). Cheap too, at $1.80 each. Don't miss the carne asada as well. Good for dining before a show at the Golden Gate Theatre.
author: Hao L.

description: I was drunk last night.  I usually like most food when I'm drunk.  But the Al Pastor Burrito I got last night was NASTY.  I didn't even finish it.  Tough, flavorless meat.  I think I got a slice of pizza afterwards.  I'm surprised I even remembered this...
author: Derrick V.

description: Yummy town!  Hablar espanol is the way to go, no doubt!!!  Had the super burrito, and way good.  What can I say, order it w/o onions and cilantro.  Good times noodle salad.
author: Nicole F.

description: My favorite burrito place. Cheap, fast, and tasty. Love the burrito mojado with lengua here. Seedy part of town but what can you do. You might have to share a table with a stranger.
author: Sandy R.

description: This is the only one of the three Cancun's I ate at when I lived in SF, and it was the best burrito I found in the city. Extraordinarily fresh, well put together burritos, and excellent portions. And of course ~$4 per (my pick was a vegetarian burrito with no sour cream) and they sell mexican coke (the drinking kind).  I just don't think you can beat it, and while 6th is not a great area, come on--nobody's going to hurt you, so take a stop in and taste the deliciousness. I hear the Mission Cancun is both cleaner and better, but I wouldn't know, and that shouldn't stop you from eating here.
author: jack p.

description:
discussing local eateries with a friend in my building, i mentioned TC.
he said the only time he went there it was during a robbery with one guy doing the gun and the cash thing, and the other guy doing lines off of a table.

That makes me happy because it's one less person ahead of me in line as i dutifully queue up for my super quesadilla suiza or my burrito with pastor and avocado.

I love this place
i would starve without it

all hail taqueria cancun

besides, half the clients are the crackhead's invisible friends... or maybe their invisible gang

so the line isnt so long really
author: Domini A.

description: This is one of my favorite places to go for a 'wetback burrito' (burrito mojado).  The green avocado salsa w/ the enchilada sauce & the cheese  slathered over the top of a steaming, hot burrito CANNOT be beat!  As mentioned elsewhere, the neighborhood is sketchy.  I only come here for lunch during the daytime.  No idea what it's like at night - nor do I really care to find out.  If you're craving a burrito and already in the neighborhood, I definitely suggest you come and check this place out!
author: Allan H.

description: Overrated. All of the meats are burnt to a crisp, and there's way too much cilantro. You could say the latter is a personal preference, but the former is certainly not. Wherefore is the decent Mexican in SOMA? It's strange that I have to go up to Church and Market to get a decent burrito, but there you have it.
author: David Y.

description:
Walked over here on a Saturday evening (in an effort to satiate influence of earlier in the restful day, and in preparation for later influences) with some friends.

Immediately reminded me of many other Mexican food places I've been in the city, picnic bench-ish seating, narrow, and similar (if not same) menu.

I ordered a super quesadilla with pastor (or is it al pastor?). It was absolutely delicious. Granted, it was loaded with oil and whatnot, but I knew what I was expecting. My friends both got burritos, and they enjoyed them. 

I gave it a 4 because it's not free food, it's not substantially different than many other hole in the wall places, but the food we had was really good and definitely at least reasonable on prices.

If it weren't for my fear of Mexican food addiction, due to taste, cost, and proximity, I'd be eating here all of the time. For now, however, I'll relegate this to the "I'm drunk, I want something tasty" and let the oil and fattiness slip away with the cognitionless haze.
author: John E.

description: it smells like they are frying up the homeless & i can not be the only person who smells this
author: J A.

description:
After my friend got punched in the face by the Apple Store, we decided we should grab some tacos. 

Hits the spot every time.
author: Arnold S.

description:
I am a huge fan of the Taqueria Cancun in the Mission and I am a solid believer that they make one of the top three burritos in the entire Bay Area.

However, this location for some reason just doesn't compare to the other ones.  The food is, theoretically, identical.  Maybe it's just that the place itself is so dirty that I leave feeling like I need to shower in a stream of disinfectant or else just give in to my transformation as a bum.  

Still, the super burrito is as good as ever and if you're in the area, say, like, going to the Warfield for a show or running late for Wicked or to catch the Civic Center Bart, then this is the to-go place for you.  In terms of tasty burritos.  They are, indeed, super.
author: Ben E.

description:
While Cancun is one of the only fast cheap places around my boyfriend's house in SoMa, and one I used to visit frequently, it made me really sad last time I was there. I always ask for no rice in my burritos, because I've had one too many rice burritos when I've ordered a meat or beans-based burrito. You cannot trick me with filler, Burrito God!
So, I went into Cancun and ordered right after I knocked the toothpick box into a bucket of horchata. The toothpicks didn't spill, but the cashier looked peeved as he fished the box out, even as I apologized profusely. I only laughed a little bit. 
I ordered a vegetarian burrito without rice "all beans", apologized again, and took my burrito. Now, I realize that maybe I was being punished by the Cancuners for defiling their horchata, but the burrito had about a tablespoon of beans, and half a cup each of sour cream and onions. No cheese. No guac. Super soggy. I don't think they usually even put onions in their burritos! Maybe the pico de gallo was just onion-heavy that night? Regardless, I think it was the worst burrito I have ever had in my life. I had to add canned refried beans when I got home.
I am willing to accept that my naughtiness might have caused my bad experience, but now I will have to go to the place next to the Arrow bar..."Chile Verde" or something. It's pretty good in a sloppy kind of way.

*2/28/07 - Here's an addendum via email that my boyfriend sent me:
"well, i got burned by them a bit today. nothing major, but god, there
is so much effing cilantro in this burrito. the bottom part is like
half cilantro. and the refried beans exploded out of it, so i got all
gooey when i unwrapped it."
author: Aimee F.

description: In addition to all the other five star reviews regarding TC, I would like to add focus in on their Tortas - . After ordering your carne asada torta - watch the master at the grill. He grills the rolls and adds a slice of tomato, fresh onion, beans, meat of choice, avocado -freshly scooped, and Mexican sour cream.  The torta is then cut into two pieces -  You will also be given two freshly made salsas (green and red) and your chips. Add an order of aqua fresca - I like their cantaloupe.  After paying roughly seven bucks, your are now ready to savor a five star torta.  enjoy
author: Wilfred L.

description: There is nary a decent burrito downtown, so when I get a burrito craving whilst at work I head here.   The place is definitley scummy, but the Cancun on 18th and Mission isn't exactly the Ritz either.  The al pastor here is quite good, and a super burrito here is 2 bucks cheaper than Si Senor and about a 100 times better.  All in all a decent burrito when you're in need of a fix.  Also if you don't like eating in the midst of hookers and drug dealers, you can always carry it over to the mall and eat in the food court while scamming on high school chicks from CoCo county.
author: Jon M.

description: At first I didn't know if this really associated with the taqueria cancuns of the mission, but after tonight, there is no mistake. super taco bliss is mine. the tacos are still made with nice big slices of avocado and the salsa is still bright green and hot as fuck. the interior of this place is the least hospitable of the three, but grab your order to go and it hardly matters. The construction is not as tight as the 19th and mission location, but it is still the right price and still the right taste.
author: Tom H.

description: Watch out... their salsa only comes way too spicy for everyone who I brought there to try it.  My burrito was notable.  I especially liked that the tortilla had been grilled a bit instead of steamed.  Added another texture to the mix.
author: ben y.

description: By the end of our honeymoon, we were ready for a good ol burritto. This place did the trick. We both had chicken burritos and boy were they heavy! They were very tasty and I couldn't even finish mine. That is a rarity. However the location is a wee sketchy which is why I'm giving them 3 stars. If you are looking for a good burrito for cheap and can take it to go, this is your place.
author: Natalie B.

description: Their burritos taste best after a long night of drinking, too bad the one downtown closes too early.  The space is a lot smaller than the Mission district one, leaving you to either take it to-go, or eat on 6th Street.
author: Mark D.

description: This was more of a spot of my youth, but when in the neighborhood and in the mood for Mexican food this is the place. The 'hood is a bit... rough. But I usually go during the day, and considering this pretty li'l 5 foot nothing female hasnt ever been messed with just goes to show.  The torta is my favorite hangover food, greasy and good. I usually get a super veggie, though I'll occasionally go for the tasty carne asada. The place is a total hole-in-the-wall, and one has to wonder abut the sanitary conditions, but I can attest that to this day I still have never had food poison from Cancun's food.
author: Mollie M.

description: An amazing veggie burrito! So tasty and the ingredients tasted fresh...even for 10pm on a Monday.
author: Anita C.

description:
While I still have a list of taquerias to try, this is my current favorite. Pancho Villa was ok, but I always felt like I was missing out on something  and there was never enough cheese in my burrito (though I'll admit that I do like a lot of cheese). Taqueria San Jose was just... wow, amazingly uninspiring.

Yeah, the neighborhood isn't great, but it's close to the BART station and I'm sure there are plenty of reasons why you'll find yourself around here (although if you happen to be in the Mission, by all means, go to one of the two locations there). The burritos and tacos are a great value ($4.50 for a burrito, $5.50 super), but are never skimpy or lacking. The start off the tortilla is grilled, not steamed. The meat is juicy and tastily grilled with plenty of flavor. The meat is complemented well by the grilled onions (I'm not a fan of onions most of the time and would never eat them raw, but don't skip them here) which really help to bring out the grilled flavor of the meat. The cilantro is a subtle accompaniment that doesn't overshadow as it so easily can. The beans and rice are both great and the cheese is gooey and plentiful. The avocado is a bit skimpy and while it's present, the flavor isn't very upfront, but I've never found this to be a problem. Plus extra credit for using avocado instead of guacamole. I take mine without sour cream and salsa so no comments there.

Some people claim that the salsa served with the chips is too spicy, but I've honestly never noticed. I'm a complete wimp for most salsas and order my buffalo wings mild or medium at the most, but I never found either salsa to be particularly spicy. The salsa verde might be a bit more potent than usually encountered, but not much. Perhaps they  have slightly changed things as most of the complaints about overly-spicy salsa seem to be a bit older. While both are acceptable, neither is outstanding. In this regard Pancho Villa proves why they have all those state fair salsa awards on their walls.

In the end I have some more places on my list to try, but at present this is my pick for the best taqueria in the city.
author: Mark S.

description:
I'm not going to lie.  This is one of those places that you walk by for years thinking its the most disgusting and filthy place ever.  Its not the kind of place you would be comfortable sitting, eating, or even breathing in.  

Then I finally succumbed.  My coworkers convinced me.  I went for lunch and it was delicious.  DELICIOUS.  I was hooked and now the one in the mission is a frequent late night inebriated munchies spot.
author: B B.

description: Only visited once, ate a chicken burrito.  The burrito had standard ingredients(beans,rice,chicken,pico de gallo.) Decent flavors, thrown together quickly.  The burrito was served with what looked like store bought tortilla chips that were stale.  Chicken chunks inside and I mean chunks. Overall flavors are good, just needs a little TLC on preparation.
author: Don I.

description: I'm not sure what all of the hype is about this place.  I found it to be mediocre in comparison to Pancho Villa.  I ordered the supernachos, which came with too much sour cream and not enough beans.  The chips were stale.  I had a stomach ache afterward.
author: Joanna S.

description:
solidified as my neighborhood burrito joint.

i know most of you gripe about sixth street when you review *anything* near it, but you need to get over it. it's not that bad - just keep moving. they're harmless.

cancun is dirt cheap, has tasty chorizo, a veggie burrito that keeps the non-omnivorous happy, and the salsa verde is probably the best i've noticed in the city.

if you're afraid of inner city, just go to another location.
author: Clover Dan ..

description:
veggie burrito: pretty good.
nachos: kinda good, too much avocado/jalapenos, though.
quesadilla: usually good, but last time i thought i saw bits of meat in my cheese-only quesadilla.  (i don't eat meat, that's not cool.)
cleanliness: kinda bad.
prices: ok, seems a bit high for what it is.

this place is good if i'm in the area and don't feel like traipsing to the mission for a burrito.  the chips are stale and the salsa is sort of old, but it does the job in a pinch.
author: Kate W.

description: Not as efficient or delicious as their cousin on Mission (at 19th).  A passable burrito by anyone's standards and still better than most, but they just pale in comparison.  Maybe it's because there isn't as much business so the food doesn't turn over as fast.  Or maybe it's the surroundings and the ambience that isn't quite right.  Either way, I'll go here in a pinch since I live nearby and it beats most of the other food in the area.
author: Frankie D.

description:
wanna try something different other than the "mexican sleeping pill" aka burrito?  i would HIGHLY recommend the enchilladas.  they are the best in the city and comes with fresh steamed tortillas for more of a hearty meal.


***oops!  this was meant for the Taqueria Cancun on Mission street at 19th street.  i know it's the same owners though but i've never gotten the enchilladas here at this location.****
author: Pickle R.

description: For a long time I tried to force myself to be into this place, as it is just a few blocks from home.  But I found myself finally being unable to deny that their burritos gave me heartburn every single time I ate them.  And they don't have fresh chips.  I just don't get why it's always being voted "best veg burrito" in this-or-that survey... because dude, there are so many better taquerias out there.
author: Sarah R.

description: I give places 3 strikes and they've long since struck out. i'm only really writing this review as a warning to anybody reading the reviews below touting this spot as a "true" taqueria. Any of the mission spots blow this joint away. i could recommend five off the top of my head that just taste better. but flavor lacking in the burritos aside, this spot hold a special place in my heart.... it's the only restaurant that has served me a burrito with big ass staple inside of it! that kinda clinches it for me as the worst taqueria in SF! it's not just bad for you it might just kill you!
author: J R.

description: Some of the best mexican food in the city, but careful of the neighborhood. Even though it's not far from the shopping district, I had my camera ganked off the table a few days ago -- not the place's fault, but something to keep in mind when going by! In any case, the guacamole is absolutely fantastic and their burritos are completely messy, aka the best kind.
author: Patrick K.

description: Quick, friendly service, enough tables but intimate, good for a quick bite.  The food is pretty authentic, fresh and clean, (none of those orange grease bombed burritos) ....if you like carne asada and you don't have a mexican mom who cooks more authentic food, you will probably like this place better than the tex mex crap that usually gets good reviews.
author: regina k.

description: Decent. Beef was dry. I asked for a carne asada super burrito. I didn't get any guac. Not enough salsa either. I've had better.
author: M W.

description: Sure, the neighborhood's a bit rough, and upon first entering you might think the place is a little dingy.  But the Vegetarian Burritos here are absolutely the best food ever!  I get a craving for these things at least twice a week, and they're more than worth putting up with the neighborhood ambiance.  Also, you can walk in with just a five in your pocket and walk out with a tasty meal.
author: Marcus M.

description: I love the veggie burritos here! I've been a customer here for the last 13 years. After having recently moved back to the city and been again, I can still say this place has the best veggie burritos. They do them nice and simple here--no tofu or soyrizo--just great beans (I prefer whole pinto, although they also have black and refried), rice, big chunks of avocado (way better than guacamole in a burrito), onion, cilantro, salsa, and cheese and sour cream (which I leave off), along with chips and 2 kinds of salsa. You will get stuffed silly for $5 and change; the burritos are enormous. One more thing, do yourself a favor and also get an agua fresca; they're delish (cantaloupe is my fave). While this location attracts a lot of transients as it's right on Market at 6th, nothing bad can be said about the food.
author: Paula L.

description: I saw Jesus in my super burrito.  Great value, and "interesting" entertainment.
author: Mel B.

description: One time when I was eating here, they were nice enough to give a homeless guy a piece of foil so that he could freebase his crack. You can't beat that for service.
author: Josh H.

description: It's hard to be a unique Mexican restaurant. I feel as though salsa is what makes the difference. If you can make a good salsa, then usually the food will be good too. This place has some yummy spicy salsa and delicious quesadillas.
author: Lucy G.

description: stumbling out of the mezzanine last month after the lady gaga show, all my girls and i wanted were some tacos. taqueria cancun did not disappoint. i wasn't even sure what the name of the place was; we asked someone on the street where to get tacos and they just said the hole in the wall around the corner. all three of us had super tacos, but we tried the beef, chicken and carnitas. the carnitas was delish and my girls' grub looked great as well. certainly helped that we were a bit drunk, but i'd go back anytime for a tasty taco.
author: Kris G.

description: You won't find many better burritos than here, and certainly not for south of $5.  Some don't like venturing past those po' homeless folks....gee, the nerve of people to want money......but really......the burritos are worth it.  I got in there at 8:57 in the morning, the door was open, and asked for the vegetarian burrito.  I was told no, they weren't open till 9.  Silly me, thinking coz the door was open they were open.  Why would a bidness that had its door open actually be open?  What a gross logical fallacy on my part.  Anyway, the burrito itself was fantastic.  Tortilla was toasted just nicely, everything just sort of melted together in the burrito.  Really, I dunno what else to say.  And their horchata is very nice too (cinnamon rice drink...I recommend it anywhere....actually good at the AM/PM).  Anyway, and you get chips and some hot-ass green salsa (make sure you have some napkins too, if you glisten...uh huh, that wasn't sweat....no, I just um, got out of the gym) like me.   Everything was good.  A fantastic veggie burrito for $3.95 and horchata for only $1.25.  I call that a good day.  Well, at least a good start to a day.
author: Todd C.

description: despite some neighborhood skeeziness (got used to it after living nearby for awhile), the burritos are quite impressive - minus the cilantro and onions (they really pile them on). boyfriend and i came here dressed to the nines after the opera one night, but we had to have that reynolds-wrap covered slab of goodness.
author: Kiki B.

description: the best super tacos in the Tenderloin/SOMA areas, it might be a little hole in the wall in a seemingly shady neighborhood, but dont be scurred, your food is completely safe!
author: binh l.

description: it took me awhile before i was sold on these guys, but now i can unequivocably declare that they make one of the best damned al pastor super burritos in the city.  everytime we eat here it makes band practice afterwards a bit more difficult - too much burrito!  and there was the time some crackhead with a trust fund got into a fight with my bass player inside!  fortunately my boy was wearing his brass knuckles, cuz his scrawny ass needed them.
author: eric i.

description: OK, this is what a call a monster burrito. I ordered the Carnitis Super Burrito, and was stunned at the size of the creation. Mind you, I didn't have any trouble at all finishing it, since it was so good. The place is tiny, and I wish they had a soda machine, but besides that is a great cheap filling meal.
author: Darin E.

description: we go there after climbing because it's close and open late.  so basically, it's just your typical mexican taqueria, where you order at the counter and go sit yourself after cleaning up.
author: Damien J.

description: The long and skinny cancun!  it's yellow!  One of my favorite places to eat in the whole world.  For lunch I often get a big fatty super carne asada burrito (and I ask for lots of the green salsa in it) and take it a couple blocks to yerba buena gardens to eat.  From there I pass out due to burrito coma joy.  Thank you cancun!
author: Benjamin P.
